title: Can the U.S. Repair Its Health Care While Keeping Its Innovation Edge?
description: The United States health care system has many problems, but it also promotes more innovation than its counterparts in other nations. Thats why discussions of remaking American health care often raise concerns about threats to innovation.

title: The New Generation of Japanese Accommodations
description: Any traveler to Japan knows that its sense of hospitality  the sober, subtle beauty of the countrys lodgings, and the elegant, unobtrusive service within them  is unmatched anywhere else. For years, visitors could choose between two kinds of hotels: the Western kind (though often reinterpreted with Japanese materials, textiles and sightlines), or the traditional Japanese inn, the ryokan. Ryokans were originally built in medieval times to keep traveling merchants in comfort, offering ofuro baths, woven tatami floors and simple breakfasts of fish, tofu, rice and pickled vegetables. The new generation of Japanese accommodations, though, are neither ryokan nor hotel: They are restored samurai-era mansions, or refit prehistorical huts or even a Baja-esque beach camp. Significantly, many are also in less expected places  small towns and regions where tourists rarely go  giving travelers a chance to explore a part of the country they might otherwise not.

title: Listen to The Daily: The A.C.L.U. and the Alt-Right
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: Nobel in Economics Is Awarded to Richard Thaler
description: WASHINGTON  Richard H. Thaler, whose work has persuaded many economists to pay more attention to human behavior, and many governments to pay more attention to economics, was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences on Monday.

title: The Latest on Lice
description: Like many other parents, Ive paid my dues when it comes to head lice. It was a while ago, back in day care, and there was a dress-up box with hats and crowns and helmets that was probably the smoking gun. We all had to do the whole routine, applying insecticide rinses to our childrens heads and washing sheets and pillow cases in hot water, and becoming somewhat fanatical about not sharing hats.

title: New Blood Pressure Guidelines for Children
description: Had Matthew Goodwins blood pressure been checked at age 3, when it should have been, he most likely would have been spared a medical emergency a year later. He spent two weeks in the pediatric intensive care unit while doctors tried to determine why his blood pressure had spiked off the charts following minor surgery.

title: Fear the Blanket, Not the Germs
description: People talk about the first glimpses of their first grandchildren in terms borrowed from romantic poetry: They swoon. They find every finger and eyelash beautiful, perfect. They melt into helpless puddles of love.

title: New York Today: Debating a Holiday
description: Good morning on this murky Monday.

title: Unintended Consequences of Sexual Harassment Scandals
description: In Silicon Valley, some male investors have declined one-on-one meetings with women, or rescheduled them from restaurants to conference rooms. On Wall Street, certain senior men have tried to avoid closed-door meetings with junior women. And in TV news, some male executives have scrupulously minded their words in conversations with female talent.

title: Columbus Day Has Drawn Protests Almost From Day 1
description: A reverend at Calvary Baptist Church in Manhattan appeared on the front page of The New York Times after he criticized Christopher Columbus, the Italian navigator who sailed to the Americas on behalf of Spain in 1492.

title: Corker Takes On Trump, Hedge Funds Lose on Puerto Rico: DealBook Briefing
description: When a senator says that President Trump is making threats that could set the United States on the path to World War III  as Senator Bob Corker told the NYT on Sunday  you might expect the entire business community to take notice.

title: Kim Jong-un of North Korea, in Rare Show of Confidence, Promotes His Sister
description: HONG KONG  Kim Jong-un has promoted his younger sister to North Koreas most important political body, a rare public gesture of confidence by a leader whose dealings with family members are often opaque and sometimes deadly.

description: Good morning.

title: The N.F.L.s Big Head-Scratcher: Whats Wrong With the Cowboys?
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Dallas Cowboys do not play next week, which ensures that they will not score four touchdowns at home and lose.

title: Trumps Masochism
description: Please stop. Gary Cohn and Steven Mnuchin are both now endangering the reputations they built up over many years in business. Theyre doing so by telling blatant untruths about President Trumps tax plan. My column today is a plea to them to stop, for their sake and for everyone elses.

title: Trauma, and Red Tape, in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  The slot machines and blackjack tables are filling up again at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, a golden tower on the southern end of the Vegas Strip. Its taken days for any sense of normalcy to return to the place where last Sunday, an itinerant gambler, Stephen Paddock, used assault rifles to rain bullets down on a country music festival, killing 58 and injuring more than 500, one of the deadliest mass shootings in United States history.

title: Joe Girardi Takes His Medicine  a Barrage of Boos in the Bronx
description: The moment of judgment arrived early, and it wasnt pretty. When Joe Girardi was introduced on Sunday night before Game 3 of the Yankees division series against the Cleveland Indians, he clambered out of the dugout to the sort of heartfelt jeers usually reserved in the Bronx for the Red Sox or Mets.

title: G.M. Acquires Strobe, Start-Up Focused on Driverless Technology
description: DETROIT  General Motors said on Monday that it had acquired a company that specializes in laser-imaging technology geared toward enhancing the development of autonomous vehicles.

title: Hassan al-Thawadi on Worker Welfare, Qatari Goals and the 2022 World Cup
description: Qatar won the right to host the 2022 World Cup seven years ago, and it still has five years to get its country ready to roll out the welcome mat. But as world soccer begins to focus more intently on the 2018 tournament in Russia this week, and the teams that will be taking part, thoughts of 2022 are never far away. Hassan al-Thawadi, the British-educated son of a diplomat leading the 2022 World Cup organizing committee, is the man tasked with putting on his countrys big show. In an interview at The New York Times last month, al-Thawadi revealed that he supports  gasp!  Lyon and not Qatari-owned Paris St.-Germain. He also discussed worker welfare, the unique challenges of hosting a World Cup in a Muslim nation, and the World Cup stadium that will have a second life as a wedding hall.

title: The Ken Burns Effect
description: With any luck, the television documentary The Vietnam War by Ken Burns and Lynn Novick may open the way for a new period of public and academic interest in the conflict. That may sound strange: How many movies, books, poems and documentaries have been made about the war, after all? A lot, of course. But with few exceptions, the conversation around the war has been stuck in neutral, focused on a few important but far from all-encompassing questions. But the Burns-Novick documentary could change that.

title: We See Others Failures as Courageous. We See Our Own as Shameful. Why?
description: Will you try something with me?

title: Leaving Flickr? How to Preserve Your Online Photo Albums
description: Q. Im deleting Yahoo and my Flickr account. In regards to Flickr, I still have most of the original images on my computer, but need to retrieve a handful of photos I cant find on my hard drive. Can I download the Flickr copies in the original resolution, or will they be in a lower image quality?

title: What Killed the Promise of Muslim Communism?
description: LONDON  For a brief moment after the Bolshevik uprisings of 1917, it looked like revolution might be waged across vast swaths of the world under the joint banner of Communism and Islam.

title: Star Trek: Discovery Season 1, Episode 4: Remain Klingon
description: After an episode-long break, the Klingons are back.

title: In Jerusalem, Looking for Peace in Backgammon and Music
description: JERUSALEM  The Old City walls echoed with the clack-clack of a backgammon tournament as Israelis and Palestinians from all walks of life tried their luck with a roll of the dice.

title: Meryl Streep, Kate Winslet and Glenn Close Speak Out on Harvey Weinstein
description: Meryl Streep led an increasingly vocal Hollywood chorus condemning the reported sexual misconduct of the Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein on Monday, issuing a carefully worded statement released  to  HuffPost. She decried the behavior as disgraceful and inexcusable, yet also pleaded ignorance about it, writing, Not everybody knew.

title: U.S. and Turkey Try to Prevent a Diplomatic Dispute From Growing
description: ISTANBUL  First, the United States and Turkey temporarily stopped issuing visas to each others citizens. Then the Turkish lira plunged on international markets, and most travel between the two countries was curtailed.

title: Salmon and Chicken
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

title: California Fires Kill at Least 10 and Destroy 1,500 Buildings
description: For the latest news on the wildfires, please read this story.

title: E.P.A. Announces Repeal of Major Obama-Era Carbon Emissions Rule
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency announced on Tuesday that Scott Pruitt, the chief of the agency, had signed a measure to repeal President Barack Obamas signature policy to curb greenhouse gas emissions from power plants, setting up a bitter fight over the future of Americas efforts to tackle global warming.

title: Not Just Rooms, Hotels Offer One-of-a-Kind Experiences
description: With competitors like Airbnb nipping at their heels, hotels are rolling out experiences to their most faithful customers that go far beyond extra nights and room upgrades.

title: Review: A Show-Off Who Doesnt Know When to Shut Up
description: The title character of George Kellys 1924 play The Show-Off is a boasting buffoon named Aubrey Piper  a vain, dissembling blowhard with an obvious toupee and galloping delusions of grandeur. Spencer Tracy starred as Aubrey in the comedys second movie adaptation, Red Skelton in the third, but the team behind the plays current Off Broadway revival seems to have taken inspiration from another star altogether.

title: Trumps Fight With Corker Jeopardizes His Legislative Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps latest rupture with a Republican senator has widened the schism with his own party on Capitol Hill, potentially jeopardizing the future of his legislative agenda even as he presses lawmakers to approve deep tax cuts, according to veteran Republicans and independent analysts.

title: An Ailey Dancer Loyal to His Miami Roots and Mentor
description: MIAMI  Jamar Roberts has been around the world as a leading dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. But a week after Hurricane Irma swept through Miami, he was back where he started, at Dance Empire, a studio in a suburban strip of warehouses here.

title: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Amazon and More in October
description: New movies and TV shows are added to streaming platforms each month. Here are the titles we think are most interesting in October.

title: How Police Surveillance Units Became Unlikely Historians
description: The photographs record a 1967 antiwar demonstration in Central Park, a 1968 protest at Columbia University and an undated gay power demonstration. There is film footage of the first Earth Day march and a rally held by the Nation of Islam.

title: Red Cross Reduces Presence in Afghanistan After Staff Is Attacked
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After 30 years of medical work during some of Afghanistans bloodiest times, the International Committee of the Red Cross said on Monday that it was drastically reducing its presence in the country after a series of attacks on its staff.

title: Germanys Angela Merkel Agrees to Limits on Accepting Refugees
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel has agreed to limit the number of asylum seekers allowed to enter Germany each year to 200,000, a concession to her Bavarian partners as she tries to form a government after losing seats to the far right in elections last month.

title: Mike Isabella, Washingtons Restless Restaurateur
description: WASHINGTON  Mike Isabella fanned himself with a hard hat as he stood on a construction site on the bank of the Potomac that workers were frantically trying to turn into a contemporary French restaurant. Permits and a liquor license had yet to materialize. The basement was nowhere near ready to receive shipments. The floors were  well, there were no floors.

title: Why Stanford Researchers Tried to Create a Gaydar Machine
description: Michal Kosinski felt he had good reason to teach a machine to detect sexual orientation.

title: The Trump Administrations Proposal to Repeal the Clean Power Plan
description: The Trump administration will file a proposal in the Federal Register to repeal the Clean Power Plan, arguing that the Obama administration exceeded its legal authority in an effort to limit greenhouse gas emissions from power plants.

title: Jonathan Lovitz, Steve Sosna
description: Jonathan David Lovitz and Steve Sosna are to be married Oct. 8 in New York Harbor aboard the Atlantica, a charter yacht. James R. Obergefell, a friend of the couple, a Universal Life minister and the named plaintiff in the lawsuit that led the Supreme Court to legalize same-sex marriage throughout the United States, is to officiate.

title: The Battle for Mosul
description: Ivor Prickett spent months on assignment for The New York Times in Mosul, Iraq, documenting the battle to recapture the city from Islamic State militants and the aftermath.

title: Being a Survivor  and Owning a Gun  in the Wake of a Mass Shooting
description: Veronica Torres and Deanna Griese were working as cocktail servers at the Route 91 Harvest Festival in Las Vegas when the mass shooting broke out. They escaped the attack together and have come out on the other side with new perspectives as gun owners.

title: The Collected Essays of Elizabeth Hardwick Gives Off a Bright Light
description: Publishers need positive notices for their books, Elizabeth Hardwick wrote, as an Easter basket needs shredded green paper under the eggs. She was determined they have fewer of them.

title: Google Finds Accounts Connected to Russia Bought Election Ads
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google has found evidence that Russian agents bought ads on its wide-ranging networks in an effort to interfere with the 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Roasted Pumpkinseeds Without All the Work
description: Stony Brook WholeHeartedFoods, in the Finger Lakes region of New York, has been selling excellent pumpkin- and squash-seed oils for several years. Now they are putting the whole seeds to another use, as snack fare. Pumpkin and butternut squash seeds are brined to soften the hulls, then roasted. They come plain and seasoned with maple or chile. You could also give the seeds a whirl as toppings for fragrant homemade autumn muffins, pumpkin pies or yogurt: Pepitas, Maple Pepitas, Butternut Pepitas and Sweet Chili Butternut Pepitas, each $3 for three ounces, or all, $14 for 16 ounces, wholeheartedfoods.com.

title: Trump Voters, Writ Large
description: To the Editor:

title: Politicians With Puerto Rican Roots Challenge Trump in Push for Aid
description: Jos E. Serrano has been elected again and again to represent a tiny, tightly packed congressional district in the South Bronx. But since the storm that ravaged Puerto Rico, the island where he lived until he was 8, another constituency far from New York City has commanded more of his attention. It is one that has never voted for him, but that he has nonetheless adopted as his own.

title: Kitchen Appliances With a 1950s Feel
description: Do you remember the Chevy Bel Air? If so, you may recognize a similar midcentury aesthetic in the Retro line from Russell Hobbs, an English maker of small appliances that came on the scene in 1952. The parent company, Spectrum Brands of Middleton, Wis., has made them available in the United States for the first time. There is an eight-cup drip coffee maker, a seven-cup kettle, and two- and four-slice toasters, all technologically advanced with features like a gauge to tell you how long your bread will take to toast and a lifter that lets you check its progress (think of that vintage Chevy with antilock brakes). The company also has a new space-age-style steel and glass line for the same appliances: Russell Hobbs appliances, $79.99 to $129.99, amazon.com.

title: Seeing India Through a Contemporary Lens
description: Near the end of his abruptly abbreviated life, Raghubir Singh complained about a curator who asked him why he didnt photograph outside India. He observed that no one wonders why Walker Evans or Garry Winogrand stayed in the United States.

title: Anna Netrebko Will Star in Three Met-Bolshoi Productions
description: MOSCOW  Two of the worlds most important opera companies, the Metropolitan Opera in New York and the Bolshoi Theater here, will collaborate on three stagings in coming years, they announced on Monday. The productions  Verdis Aida, Strausss Salome and Wagners Lohengrin  will all star the Russian diva Anna Netrebko.

title: Y.A. Tittle, Quarterback Who Led Giants to 3 Title Games, Dies at 90
description: Y. A. Tittle, the Hall of Fame quarterback who led the Giants to three consecutive National Football League championship games in the early 1960s after the San Francisco 49ers had discarded him as too old and too slow, died on Sunday night in Stanford, Calif. He was 90.

title: Jemele Hill Suspended by ESPN After Response to Jerry Jones
description: Jemele Hill, the SportsCenter host on ESPN whose tweets last month calling President Trump a white supremacist caused the White House to call for her firing, was suspended on Monday for once again running afoul of the companys social media policy.

title: Chris Foerster, Seen Snorting Powder in Video, Resigns as a Dolphins Coach
description: The Miami Dolphins offensive line coach, Chris Foerster, resigned on Monday after a video was posted online showing him snorting a powdery white substance.

title: The Future of Food Is Up for Discussion
description: A panel discussion led by Dana Cowin, the former editor of Food & Wine magazine, will explore the future of food. Susan Ungaro, the retiring president of the James Beard Foundation, and Padma Lakshmi, a cook, author and a host of Top Chef, are among the experts participating in The Next Big Bite: How We Will Eat and Drink, sponsored by Les Dames dEscoffier: Oct. 16, 5:30 to 8:30 p.m. with a reception till 6:45 p.m. when the discussion begins; $85 general admission and $115 (reserved seating and a book), Institute for Culinary Education, 225 Liberty Place (West Street), Third Floor, ldny.org.

title: New Book Glorifies the Cocktail Basics
description: Most classic cocktails  the martini, manhattan, daiquiri, old fashioned, Rob Roy, margarita, and gin and tonic  do not require more than three ingredients. And these days, when farm-to-barstool mixologists plunder Greenmarkets, back bars and spice caravans for their concoctions, its refreshing to revisit these basics, as Robert Simonson, a spirits expert who reports for The New York Times, has done in his new book. He is all for simplifying. Yet at the same time, you may make some winning discoveries, like the Alaska, a drink combining gin, yellow Chartreuse and bitters: 3-Ingredient Cocktails by Robert Simonson (Ten Speed Press, $18.99).

title: Shania Twain Returns to No. 1 With Her First Album in 15 Years
description: On the music charts this week, Shania Twain returns to No. 1 after a 15-year absence, and Tom Petty had a huge surge in sales and streams following the news of his death.

title: For a New Capsule Collection, Loewe Looks Back
description: The Northern Irish designer Jonathan Anderson is a self-described completist. When he joined Loewe, the Spanish luxury house hes helmed since 2013, he reworked the brand in obsessive detail  from the logo to the hangers. I have to design everything, hes said.

title: Mr. Robot: What to Remember Before Watching Season 3
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation website. For great suggestions of what to watch straight to your inbox, subscribe to our three-times weekly newsletter here.

title: 7 Richard Thaler Columns That Explain How Human Behavior Affects Economics
description: Richard H. Thaler, who won the 2017 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, is no stranger to our pages. Here are some of his notable columns. They exemplify his career-long efforts at humanizing economics, showing how the behavior of real people affects economic activity.

title: Kim Jong-un, Catalonia, Turkey: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Raghubir Singh, Indias Color Pioneer
description: A retrospective opening at the Met Breuer shows Singh straddling the chasm that separates modernist street photography and traditional Indian culture.

title: A Revolution in Jazz? An Avant-Garde Festival Makes History, but Not Community
description: PHILADELPHIA  From Thursday through Sunday, audiences at FringeArts in this citys historic district heard a saxophone distorted through six effects pedals squealing at peak volume, surrealist absurdism from a heritage jazz ensemble, atonal electric harp, and solo flute played in vehement gusts over a track of looming electronics.

title: Even at $15 an Hour, Need Is Close By
description: This past week, Randall Woodfin, a young Alabama city attorney, unseated a two-term Democratic incumbent to become the mayor of Birmingham. Mr. Woodfins campaign, which was committed to Trump resistance, brought him national attention and successful fund-raising in New York and Washington. Central to his progressive platform was a proposal to drive up Birminghams minimum wage, after a move last year to bring the citys rate to $10.10 an hour was quickly undercut by the State Legislature. Mr. Woodfin maintains a more ambitious agenda, to eventually get the citys minimum wage to $15 an hour.

title: Selfies in Art Museums
description: To the Editor:

title: International Center of Photography to Move Again
description: The International Center of Photography is on the move again. A year after settling into a $23.5 million exhibition space on the Bowery, the center announced that it will pack up and head to Essex Crossing, becoming the cultural anchor of this Lower East Side complex and uniting the institutions museum and school.

title: Vision Loss and Aging
description: To the Editor:

title: Forest, Forest Everywhere. But Not an Acre to Touch.
description: HORICON, N.Y.  Here in the heart of the Adirondacks, the slender Schroon River, meandering through dense stands of hemlock and white pine, is so narrow that you could easily hurl a polished rock from one bank to the other. But ever since a century-old bridge nearby closed several years ago, crossing the river by car here can take up to 10 minutes more.

title: Listen to Our Exclusive Interview with Senator Bob Corker
description: In audio excerpts from an interview with Jonathan Martin, a New York Times reporter, Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, spoke about President Trump's tweets and what Mr. Trumps twitter feed means for diplomacy.

title: Liberias Women Warn Male Presidential Candidates: Keep the Peace
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  On the eve of a presidential election that will almost certainly return male rule to Liberia after 12 years, women delivered a warning.

title: Consequences of Easing the Birth Control Mandate
description: To the Editor:

title: Las Vegas Massacre Gives InfoWars More Conspiracy Fodder
description: The mystery of why Stephen Paddock smuggled an arsenal into a Las Vegas hotel room before firing into a crowd of concertgoers, killing dozens and injuring hundreds, has only deepened in the days since the massacre. His motives remain elusive, his beliefs unclear.

title: U.S.-Puerto Rico Basketball Game to Be Moved Because of Hurricane Damage
description: The devastation wreaked by Hurricane Maria will force Puerto Rico to move its World Cup basketball qualifying game next month against the United States, according to two people with direct knowledge of the situation.

title: How to Have a Better Relationship
description: Good relationships dont happen overnight. They take commitment, compromise, forgiveness and most of all  effort. Here we offer the latest in relationship science, expert advice, fun quizzes and helpful tips to help you build a stronger bond with your partner.

title: Weinstein Company Joins Ranks of Firms With Bosses Who Misbehave
description: Theres no such thing as a founder who goes quietly. The Weinstein Company, the film studio that fired one of its two co-founder brothers amid sexual harassment allegations, now joins other companies, like Fox News and Uber, that parted ways with influential bosses who misbehaved or stood idly by while others did. Theres dual risk, both from what the departing founder takes away and what he leaves behind.

title: Ice Cream Inspired by a Syrian Pastry
description: The newest flavor of Adirondack Creamery ice cream recalls a pastry popular in Syria called maamoul, combining dates and walnuts. Translated into ice cream, its a nubbly, lightly sweetened confection with calls for unity plastered on the container. Peace, it proclaims in English, Arabic and Hebrew. We are all immigrants, it adds, and outlines the plight of Syrian refugees. Fifty percent of the profit from each pint is being donated to the International Rescue Committees efforts on their behalf: Adirondack Creamery Syrian Date & Walnut Ice Cream, $5.99 to $7.49 depending on the store; available at Kalustyans, Greene Grape Provisions, Fairway, Gourmet Garage and Fresh Direct.

title: A 3-Way Debate Is Expected to Be a 2-on-1 Against de Blasio
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio and two of his general election opponents will face off in a televised debate Tuesday night that could produce a few sparks  but not if the mayor can help it.

title: Lena Dunham: Harvey Weinstein and the Silence of the Men
description: I went to Hollywood when I was 23. I had made a low-budget film, won an award at a prestigious festival, scored an agent and made a TV deal all within six months. It was a fairy tale most people will never experience, and I knew, as well as a 23-year-old can know anything, that I was getting a pretty great deal. I bounced from meeting to meeting with the joy of Cinderella at the ball.

title: Harvey Weinsteins Fall From Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Trumps Cuts to Health Law Enrollment Efforts Are Hitting Hard
description: WASHINGTON  Michigan Consumers for Health Care, a nonprofit group, has enrolled thousands of people in health insurance under the Affordable Care Act and was honored last year as one of the nations top performers  a super navigator that would serve as a mentor to enrollment counselors in other states.

title: Trump White House Reality Show Recap: An Ex-Wife Claims First Lady Title
description: WASHINGTON  In a time of several threatening international crises, an explosive exchange came out of the Trump White House on Monday that had nothing to do with a foreign adversary. The target was a former wife.

title: Los Angeles Times Names Lewis DVorkin as Top Editor
description: LOS ANGELES  The Los Angeles Times said on Monday that it had named Lewis DVorkin, previously a senior executive at Forbes, its top editor.

title: Catalonia Independence Fight Produces Some Odd Bedfellows
description: BARCELONA, Spain  What links an anarchist youth group, a conservative party of free marketeers and a left-wing party committed instead to enhancing the welfare state?

title: Submit Questions for Choire Sicha, The Timess New Styles Editor
description: The Reader Center is a newsroom initiative that is helping The Times build deeper ties with our audience.

title: After White House Issues Demands, Hopes for an Immigration Deal Dim
description: WASHINGTON  The list of hard-line immigration demands that President Trump said he needs to back protections for young undocumented immigrants triggered a furious response on Monday from Democrats and immigration activists, who gave no indication they were willing to strike any deal.

title: Margarets Three Things to Watch This Week
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

title: Whats Going On in This Graph? | Oct. 10, 2017
description: Updated: Oct. 10, 2018

title: The New York Times is creating a residency
description: The New York Times is creating a residency for journalists who write, shoot, and share stories on social.

title: China Hastens the World Toward an Electric-Car Future
description: SHENZHEN, China  There is a powerful reason that automakers worldwide are speeding up their efforts to develop electric vehicles  and that reason is China.

title: A Bridge That Spans Cultures
description: Dear Diary:

title: Clean Power Plan, Harvey Weinstein, N.F.L.: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: One Model, 41 Beauty Looks
description: In the past month, the American model Cara Taylor walked 41 runways across the four fashion capitals  each with a different hair-and-makeup look. This time, there was more of an emphasis on natural beauty, she noted, instead of the no-makeup look that actually requires gobs of products. At some shows, they put on a tiny bit of foundation, and thats all. Backstage, she learned that to keep lips moisturized, you should use lip conditioner and not Chapstick, because Chapstick is mostly a protector, she shared, a tip worth keeping in mind year-round. Here, Taylors season of beauty looks, in pictures.

title: Full Frontal With Samantha Bee Parts Ways with Showrunner
description: Jo Miller, the executive producer and head writer of Full Frontal with Samantha Bee since its debut in 2016, has parted ways with the show, the network confirmed on Monday.

title: Boos and Rain Greet de Blasio at Columbus Day Parade
description: Like a climactic scene in an Italian melodrama, all the main characters in New Yorks political imbroglio over monuments of historical figures, and what to do with them, emerged Monday on the rain-doused Columbus Day parade route up Fifth Avenue.

title: Trumps Immigration Rhetoric Echoes a Bitter Fight in the 90s
description: Border fences, deportations, and putting America First. It all happened in the 1990s, and it started in California.

title: Trump Is Going to Make a Huge Mistake on the Iran Deal
description: President Trump is expected this week to refuse to recertify that Iran is complying with the 2015 nuclear deal, a milestone diplomatic agreement that prevents Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon.

title: Stephen Miller, the Young Man With Trumps Ear
description: President Trumps 32-year-old senior adviser has gained attention for his hard-line stances in support of the president. Glenn Thrush takes a look at Mr. Miller, from his days as a young conservative to his current role in the White House.

title: Trumps Argument Against Immigrants: Weve Heard It Before
description: Though the roots of most Americans lie in other lands, there is among them a streak of xenophobia that can be broad. Chinese and Irish immigrants were the targets of nativist hostility in the 19th century, as were Eastern European Jews and Southern Italians in the early 20th. Japanese-Americans were confined to detention camps in World War II. Now the unwelcome mat is spread for many Latinos and Muslims.

title: Herv Leroux, Creator of the Herv Lger Bandage Dress, Dies at 60
description: Herv L. Leroux, who created the figure-hugging Herv Lger bandage dresses once beloved by celebrities and the jet set, and who became a fashion cautionary tale after he lost the rights to the name Lger, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 60.

title: Liam Cosgrave, Irish Premier Who Helped End Violence, Dies at 97
description: Liam Cosgrave, a dour and dogged former prime minister of Ireland whose ingrained devotion to political stability in the 1970s helped break his countrys cycle of violence, died on Wednesday in Dublin. He was 97.

title: Right and Left React to Senator Bob Corkers Rebuke of Trump
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: Quandary in Las Vegas: What to Do With the Murder Scenes
description: LAS VEGAS  The scene of carnage this time was a flat 15-acre parcel of land without any permanent structures. It is a rectangle of blacktop surrounded by busy streets, including the famous Las Vegas Strip. Marketed as Las Vegas Village the past couple of years, it has the feel of a small county fairground. There are a few white corporate-style tents on its edges, and a large concert stage at the south end. It has been used to hold small music festivals and rodeos.

title: The Timess Executive Editor Responds to Questions About Earlier Weinstein Reporting
description: Some readers have asked us about a piece by Sharon Waxman, a former reporter for The New York Times who went on to found the entertainment news website The Wrap. Ms. Waxman writes that Times editors gutted a story she reported in 2004 on sexual harassment allegations against Harvey Weinstein.

title: Before Firing, Harvey Weinstein Asked Film Insiders to Defend Him
description: LOS ANGELES  Late Thursday, Harvey Weinstein called top Hollywood talent agents to ask for a substantial favor: to please speak up in his defense as he contended with sexual harassment allegations stretching back decades.

title: A Doctors Abandoned Journey Into Isolated Puerto Rico
description: CAONILLAS, Utuado, P.R.  Dr. Lissette Gutierrez is normally not one to curse. But when the S.U.V. she was traveling in hit a rut and bounced wildly on a mud road carved into a mountainside  a steep decline inches to her right, the pounding rain all around  an expletive escaped her lips like some rare ugly moth.

title: On Immigration, Mr. Trump Shows Congress Its on Its Own
description: It took a lawmaker who is retiring to admit what most Republicans know is their biggest obstacle to getting anything done  a president they cant depend on or trust.

title: Read Excerpts From Senator Bob Corkers Interview With The Times
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, responded to President Trumps tweets on Sunday in an on-the-record phone interview with Jonathan Martin, a Times political reporter.

title: I Have the Energy: Dianne Feinstein Makes Case for a 6th Term
description: LOS ANGELES  She is the oldest member of the United States Senate. Shes lasted through four presidents, at least two wars, one impeachment and the election of Donald J. Trump.

title: A Jail Stay Kept Secret for an Accused Terrorist
description: When Abdulrahman El Bahnasawy, then an 18-year-old from Canada, was arrested in May 2016, he was secretly detained in New York by federal authorities who hoped to arrest others in a supposed plot to detonate bombs in Times Square and in the subways.

title: When Christian Pulisic Is So Good It Hurts
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago  For one morning, the rain did what opponents of the United States mens national team have been unable to do: It penned in Christian Pulisic, denying him the space on the wings where he causes so much trouble for defenders.

title: Armando Caldern Sol, Who Led El Salvador After War, Dies at 69
description: Armando Caldern Sol, the first president elected in El Salvador after 12 years of civil war, died on Monday in Houston. He was 69.

title: How Russia Harvested American Rage to Reshape U.S. Politics
description: YouTube videos of police beatings on American streets. A widely circulated internet hoax about Muslim men in Michigan collecting welfare for multiple wives. A local news story about two veterans brutally mugged on a freezing winter night.

title: Nora Johnson, Author of The World of Henry Orient, Dies at 84
description: Nora Johnson, a novelist and memoirist who had an early success with The World of Henry Orient, which was later made into a film with the help of her screenwriter father, Nunnally Johnson, died on Thursday in Dallas. She was 84.

title: Disabled Parents Sue New York City Over Child Removals
description: Shantell lifted her 11-month-old daughter onto her right hip and looked into her eyes until she smiled. Then, she locked her long arms as if to make a swing and swayed the toddler back and forth.

title: Cubs Beat Nationals as a Bloop Cancels Out a Blunder
description: CHICAGO  The Washington Nationals got six no-hit innings from Max Scherzer. They got a big break on a defensive blunder by the Chicago Cubs Kyle Schwarber. Their left-handed specialist, Oliver Perez, got a weak pop-up from Anthony Rizzo in a clutch spot.

title: Did Californias Wildfires Force You to Evacuate?
description: Wildfires are raging across Northern California, forcing the evacuations of thousands there and in the southern part of the state.

title: The E.P.A.s Smoke and Mirrors on Climate
description: The Trump administration has mangled the costs and benefits of one of the most significant climate regulations of the Obama years in an effort to justify its repeal, which Scott Pruitt, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, announced on Monday.

title: Las Vegas Gunman Shot Security Guard Before, Not After, Targeting Concertgoers
description: LAS VEGAS  The gunman who killed 58 people and wounded hundreds more at a country music festival here last week shot a hotel security guard before, not after, opening fire on concertgoers hundreds of yards away, the authorities said on Monday, a significant shift in their timeline.

title: Quotation of the Day: Honor Goes to Expert in Harnessing the Power of Irrational Behavior
description: This is quite a funny question. I will try to spend it as irrationally as possible.

title: Review: {my lingerie play}, a Glitter-Dusted, Song-Filled Call for Liberation
description: Rattlestick Playwrights Theater is one of those tiny downtown spaces where you have to climb onstage to get to the bathroom. Before curtain time, people queue up to use the facilities while theyre still available, because once the performance starts, youre out of luck.

title: On the Periodic Table
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Im always amazed by the variety of talents and professional skills that New York Times crossword constructors bring to the table. Some are musicians, some are scientists, all of them are very smart. Theyre definitely an erudite bunch, and Mark MacLachlan is no exception: Hes a chemist who was last seen taking us on a cruciverbal roller coaster ride.

title: Wildfires Scorch Northern California
description: Northern California is being hit by ferocious wildfires, leading to more than a dozen deaths and some 20,000 evacuees.

title: The Indians Andrew Miller Falls Back to Earth
description: Few pitchers have enjoyed a better rate of success in the postseason than Andrew Miller, the dominant reliever for the Cleveland Indians. Lanky, left-handed and able to unleash bat-incinerating sliders at will, Miller did not allow a run in the first 14 postseason appearances of his career.

title: New Trailer: Star Wars: The Last Jedi
description: Look whos back! Fans saw more of Mark Hamills Luke Skywalker in the 154-second trailer unveiled Monday night for Star Wars: The Last Jedi, than they did in the entire 135-minute running time of Star Wars: The Force Awakens in 2015. That film featured only a brief glimpse of the Jedi knight in its final scene, but he appears to be back in force for the next installment.

title: A World Without Nuclear Weapons
description: In a year when the threat of nuclear war seemed to draw closer, the Nobel committee awarded the Peace Prize to a group that worked on an international treaty to ban nuclear weapons, while acknowledging that the treaty would not in itself eliminate a single nuclear weapon.

title: Texas Tech Student in Custody After Campus Police Officer Is Fatally Shot
description: HOUSTON  A college freshman shot and killed a campus police officer at Texas Tech University in Lubbock on Monday night after the student was taken to the university police station for questioning in a drug-related case, the authorities said.

title: Yankees Pounce on Indians Errors and Send Series to Game 5
description: October baseball carries a distinct, rarefied atmosphere. Managerial decisions that are easily forgotten in June become enduring. Roles that are well defined in July are scrapped in service of the here and now. And crowds that might have one eye on the action in August are hanging on every pitch.

description: John Green has written a new young adult novel, his first since The Fault in Our Stars (2012), and in some ways it is very much a John Green production.

description: How would you design your ideal school building?

title: Before and After Photos: Fires Tear Through Californias Wine Country
description: Images, including before and after views, reveal the scale of the devastation.

title: 5 Things Around Your Home You Never Clean but Should
description: You have the basics down: doing laundry, keeping the bathroom clean, wiping the kitchen countertops  but dirt and grime have a bad habit of collecting in the strangest places, including the ones you dont think to look. Here are some spots around your house you should consider cleaning more often, if you clean them at all, because theyre probably pretty filthy.

title: Teaching Activities for: White House Makes Hard-Line Demands for Any Dreamers Deal
description: Before reading the entire article:

title: In Search of the Balkan Soul
description: Thodoris Nikolaou has spent the last few years crisscrossing the Balkan Peninsula to create a visual mosaic of the regions stories and people.

title: Corker Told the Truth About Trump. Now He Should Act on It.
description: Over the past few months, the country has been in a foul sort of trance. Among people who work in politics, Republicans as well as Democrats, it is conventional wisdom that President Trump is staggeringly ill-informed, erratic, reckless and dishonest. (He also might be compromised by a hostile foreign power.) But its also conventional wisdom that with few exceptions, Republicans in Congress are not going to stand up to him. Americas nuclear arsenal is in the hands of a senescent Twitter troll, but those with political power have refused to treat this fact as a national emergency. Thus, even though a majority of Americans consider the president unfit for office, a fatalistic sense of stasis has set in.

title: Gretchen Carlson: How to Encourage More Women to Report Sexual Harassment
description: Another day, another set of headlines about a powerful man who sexually harassed women for decades, without any repercussions besides writing checks to keep his victims quiet. The accusations  against Harvey Weinstein are dreadful, but the pace at which similar stories have emerged recently is mind-numbing. From Susan Fowlers essay about her experiences at Uber to Taylor Swifts testimony about a former radio host to Ashley Judds account of encounters with Mr. Weinstein, the floodgates have opened on sexual-harassment revelations. Heads up, predators. The story isnt just that Mr. Weinstein has been fired. Its that womens voices are finally being heard.

title: Our Stupid Gun Debate
description: Bret Stephens: I know well have to bring this conversation around to the Twitter feud between President Trump and Senator Bob Corker. But I dont think we can begin with any subject other than Las Vegas. Everyone seems to want to understand the murderers state of mind. That strikes me as largely beside the point. What do you think?

title: Country Joes Obscene Truths
description: It was time for the second act on the second day of a 1969 music festival in upstate New York, but the band, Santana, was having trouble getting it together. So the M.C. asked a performer hanging around backstage to go out and kill a little time. Reticent at first because his band was slated to play later that weekend, the singer acquiesced after he was handed a Yamaha FG 150 guitar, tied with a rope in lieu of a strap, and ushered onstage.

title: Want to Vote Next Year, New York? Act Now!
description: The impresario Sol Hurok and the philosopher Yogi Berra expounded similarly on human behavior and public events: If people dont want to come, nothing can stop them. Their wry wisdom certainly applies to New York City voters. Nothing has stopped them from not showing up at the polls.

title: The Art of Thinking Well
description: Richard Thaler has just won an extremely well deserved Nobel Prize in economics. Thaler took an obvious point, that people dont always behave rationally, and showed the ways we are systematically irrational.

title: Campus Hate Lives on the Internet. Administrators Need to Catch Up.
description: Is there a difference between real life and the digital realm?

title: Shouldnt Doctors Control Hospital Care?
description: Who ultimately should be in charge of care at our nations hospitals  physicians or businesspeople?

title: Giving Capitalism a Social Conscience
description: For more than 40 years, Muhammad Yunus, the Bangladeshi founder of the Grameen Bank and recipient of the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize, has been asserting that the most powerful way to eradicate poverty is to unleash the untapped entrepreneurial capacity of people everywhere. Poverty is not created by poor people, he says. Its created by the system we built. Poor people are like a bonsai tree. You take the best seed from the tallest tree in the forest, but if you put it in a flower pot to grow, it grows only a meter high. Theres nothing wrong with the seed. The problem is the size of the pot. Society doesnt give poor people the space to grow as tall as everybody else. This is the crux of the matter.

title: Virginia Is for Haters
description: Why is America the only wealthy nation that doesnt guarantee essential health care for all? (Weve made a lot of progress under Obamacare, but not enough, and the Trump administration is doing its best to kill it.) Why do we have much higher poverty than our economic peers, especially among children, and much higher infant mortality despite the sophistication of our medical system?

title: Is This Ad Racist?
description: If you didnt see the ad, watch this version here, with commentary from CNNMoney. (The advertiser has pulled the original.) What message does it communicate to you?

title: In Search of the Balkan Soul
description: Thodoris Nikolaou has spent the last three years  and counting  crisscrossing the Balkan Peninsula to create a visual mosaic of the regions people and their stories. But for Mr. Nikolaou, the project, called Balkaniotheque and sponsored by the Onassis Foundation, became more than a multifaceted look at the region. It has been a search for his very identity.

title: Review: Money Cant Buy the New Dynasty Excitement
description: One thing that matters in business is timing. If nothing else, the CWs reboot of Dynasty knows it has that, and it lets you know quick.

title: Dear Match Book: Im Seeking Newsy Nonfiction That Sparks Debate
description: Dear Match Book,

title: Readers Speak Out on Goals and Challenges of Women Today
description: In connection with our Women Today section, which was tied to the Womens Forum for the Economy and Society in Paris on Oct. 5 and 6, we asked readers what were the challenges facing women in the work force and what did they think needed to be done to support their needs? Here are some of the responses we received.

title: The Prophet of Germanys New Right
description: Gtz Kubitschek, a self-proclaimed rightist intellectual, lives in a medieval manor house in Schnellroda, a rural village in eastern Germany. From this isolated, antique outpost, Kubitschek, who is 47, wields considerable influence over far-right thinkers, activists and politicians across Germany, who make regular pilgrimages to Schnellroda for an audience with him. The manor serves as the headquarters for the magazine and publishing house that Kubitschek runs with his wife, the writer Ellen Kositza, and also for a rightist think tank, the plainly named Institute for State Policy, and a small organic farm where he raises rabbits and goats. Kubitschek calls himself a conservative, battling to preserve Germanys ethno-cultural identity, which he says is threatened by immigration and the alienating effects of modernity. He identifies as part of the German New Right, which seeks to dissociate itself from the old right, which in Germany means Nazis. German political scientists, by contrast, classify the brand of thinking Kubitschek ascribes to as either an ideological hinge between conservatism and right-wing extremism, or as simply extremist  not vastly different, in other words, from the old right. Kubitschek, however, presents his views with a disarming, Teutonic idealism that recalls a Germany that long preceded the rise of Hitler. The German magazine Der Spiegel once referred to him as a dark knight.

title: What if a Bear Took an N.B.A. Stars Place? Shea Serrano Has an Answer
description: Shea Serrano, the sportswriter and the San Antonio Spurs virtual cheerleader, made a name for himself by finding humor in the mundane on his Twitter feed. He has 169,000 followers and climbing. But what really brought him fame was the 2015 best-selling book The Rap Year Book, a laugh-out-loud, year-by-year argument for the best songs in hip-hop. Now, he is back with another eagerly anticipated, illustrated book, Basketball (and Other Things): A Collection of Questions Asked, Answered, Illustrated, which will be published Tuesday. Sample question: If 1997 Karl Malone and a bear swapped places for a season, who would be more successful?

title: Exploring the Necessity and Virtue of Sleep
description: SNOOZE The Lost Art of Sleep By Michael McGirr 311 pp. Pegasus Books. $26.95.

title: Are Politicians Responsible for Their Base, or Is It the Other Way Around?
description: Last month, Alabama conducted a novel political experiment, conscripting the states Republican voters as its lab rats. The question that was officially on the ballot was whom the party should nominate for the United States Senate seat vacated by Attorney General Jeff Sessions in February. One option was Luther Strange, a former state attorney general, who had filled the seat since being appointed by a Republican governor who happened to be under investigation by Stranges own office. The other was Roy Moore, a twice-defrocked State Supreme Court justice described last month by the conservative National Review as nothing more than a bigoted, theocratic and ignorant buffoon, who has argued variously that Muslims shouldnt be allowed in Congress, that homosexuality should be illegal, that multiple Midwestern communities are currently governed by Shariah law and that the Sept. 11 attacks might have been divine punishment for Americas sins.

title: No Country for Young Widows
description: SAVAGE COUNTRY By Robert Olmstead 304 pp. Algonquin. $26.95.

title: If the Boy Had Pneumonia, Why Did He Have Odd Sores on His Body?
description: Is he a healthy kid? Dr. Ingrid Polcari asked the boys father. He certainly looked healthy to the young dermatologist, except for the ugly, nickel-size sore that marred his otherwise smooth, plump cheek. The 5-year-olds father had taken him in because of three awful-looking sores that appeared out of nowhere. The first one, near the right elbow, erupted a few weeks earlier; the second, on the left calf, a few days after; and the third one, on the face, just after that. His pediatrician had tried a couple of different antibiotic pills and creams, but the lesions just kept getting bigger and uglier.

title: In-Demand Destinations for Winter, From Portugal to Australia
description: Where are residents of the United States traveling this fall and winter? Pretty much everywhere. The 10 most popular vacation destinations cover nearly every continent, even Antarctica, compared with several years ago, when the lineup wasnt nearly as diverse.

title: Early Days on the 747: Power, Style and Size
description: The 747, one of historys most iconic airplanes, is heading toward retirement. Mark Vanhoenacker, a pilot and the author of Skyfaring: A Journey with a Pilot, writes that for those who grew up under 747-crossed skies, it can be hard to appreciate how revolutionary the jets dimensions were when it first (and improbably, to some observers) got airborne in 1969. Here is a look at how the plane was marketed by the airlines that adopted it, and how The New York Times covered its (sometimes rocky) early days.

title: A Fisherman Tries Farming
description: Joe Young, who spent decades catching lobsters, has turned to growing oysters. Even with lobsters flourishing, more people are trying aquaculture in Maine.

title: The Boeing 747 Slowly Readies to Retire
description: The Boeing 747, known as the Queen of the Skies, changed the history of aviation. A pilot shares the story of how he fell in love with it.

title: As the 747 Begins Its Final Approach, a Pilot Takes a Flight Down Memory Lane
description: How much do I, a Boeing 747 pilot, love the airplane that I fly? Its tough, and maybe a little embarrassing, to answer. But as the iconic jets eventual retirement draws closer, I am surely not the only 747 fan whos taking some very long flights down memory lane.

title: New York Architects Chosen for Major New London Concert Hall
description: LONDON  The high-profile American architectural practice Diller Scofidio & Renfro has been chosen to design the Center for Music, a future home for the London Symphony Orchestra and the Guildhall School of Music and Drama. It will be the first major project in Britain for the practice, which has been responsible for the High Line in New York, the Broad Museum in Los Angeles and Zaryadye Park in Moscow, among other projects, and is working on the renovation of New Yorks Museum of Modern Art and the design of The Shed, a new arts center on the west side of Manhattan designed in collaboration with Rockwell Group.

title: Harvey Weinstein Draws Sharp Attacks From Late-Night Hosts
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: Doubtful Science Behind Arguments to Restrict Birth Control Access
description: In a new rule about coverage of contraception, the Trump administration argues against the positives of birth control and highlights potential harms. But those claims dont stand up to scrutiny.

title: For Belfast, America First Amounts to Northern Ireland Last
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  When President Trump championed his America first trade policy during the election campaign, George Burnside could not have known that he, a veteran aircraft fitter, would be among the policys first potential casualties.

description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: John Green Tells a Story of Emotional Pain and Crippling Anxiety. His Own.
description: Two years ago, the novelist John Green was unable to control his thoughts. His mind played relentlessly over the same fears and anxieties. At times, he couldnt focus enough to read a menu or follow the plot of a television show, much less write a book.

description: Good morning on this splendid Tuesday.

title: Travel Tips From Comedians: Marc Maron
description: Like most stand-up comedians, Marc Maron has to travel a lot to do his job. But to do what hes become best known for, his podcast, WTF With Marc Maron, his guests mostly come to him (to his garage, specifically, in the Highland Park neighborhood of Los Angeles).

title: Japan and Utility Are Found Negligent Again in Fukushima Meltdowns
description: TOKYO  A district court in Fukushima, the site of the nuclear meltdowns in 2011 that forced thousands of people to evacuate their homes, ruled on Tuesday that the Japanese government and the electric utility that operated the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant must pay damages totaling roughly $4.4 million to about 2,900 people.

title: Australian Cybersecurity Report Shows Gaps in Private Companies Defenses
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The Australian government presented its annual cybersecurity report on Tuesday, revealing that one of its national security contractors had suffered a breach in which it lost a significant amount of data last year.

description: TOKYO  Big manufacturers of cars, aircraft and bullet trains have long relied on Kobe Steel to provide raw materials for their products, making the steel maker a crucial, if largely invisible, pillar of the Japanese economy.

Start-Up Bets on Tech Talent Pipeline From Africa

title: Palestinian Rivals Talk Unity but Show Divisions
description: JERUSALEM  As the rival Palestinian factions Fatah and Hamas began unity talks on Tuesday in Cairo, one detail stood out as emblematic of the challenges they face: The delegation representing Hamas is led by a man who has been accused of plotting to overthrow the president of the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Eric Gundersen, the chief executive of a mapping start-up called Mapbox, met Masayoshi Son, the head of the Japanese conglomerate SoftBank, in late July, he expected to have to sell Mr. Son on what made Mapbox important.

title: Spotting Those MacBook Battery Burners
description: Q. My MacBook Air is less than a year old, but I notice the battery doesnt seem to last nearly as long as advertised and the laptop seems to really be working at something. How can I tell what its doing?

title: Profile in Style: Ilse Crawford
description: The London-based designer shares her passions and inspirations.

title: Ilse Crawfords Unerring Eye
description: The London-based designer Ilse Crawford doesnt believe genes are destiny. Yet she knows that her career  which includes introducing modern style to England in the 1980s as founding editor of British Elle Decoration and gaining global acclaim for her interiors at Manhattans Soho House  seems like a product of her parentage. Her Danish mother was an artist; her Canadian father was the economics editor of The Sunday Times of London. I have both the analytical and the instinctual, she says. Working at a magazine taught me how to communicate my ideas, but like an artist, Im willing to make some mistakes.

title: After 6,000 Years of Human Habitation, One Family and Lots of Mice
description: ERBIL, Iraq  There are two ways to consider the imposing Erbil citadel, a huge mound 100 feet above the flat plain on which this city of one million sits.

title: 8 Pairs of Exotic, Graphic Mules
description: The backless slipper gets updated for autumn with ornate embroidery and Moroccan-style embellishments.

title: Honeywell Set to Spin Off 2 Units, but Keep Aerospace Division
description: LONDON  The American technology and manufacturing company Honeywell announced on Tuesday that it planned to spin off parts of its business but would retain its aerospace technology operations, against the recommendations of an activist investor.

title: Rationality and Rabbit Holes
description: Like the vast majority of economists, I was delighted to see Richard Thaler get the Nobel. Anyone with a bit of sense  a group that, believe it or not, includes many economists  knows that people arent perfectly rational. But the assumption of hyperrationality still plays far too large a role in the field. And Thaler didnt just document deviations from rationality, he showed that there are consistent, usable patterns in those deviations.

title: A New Building Mimics Old SoHo
description: A developer has designed a new building to reflect the style of existing SoHo structures, with an unusual cornice and loft-life apartments.

title: SoHo Gets Something New
description: SoHo is not an easy place to build. Empty lots are scarce. Many buildings require their residents to be working artists. And the neighborhood sits almost entirely in a historic district.

title: The End of Moes Meat Market
description: Moes Meat Market, in Little Italy, hasnt been a meat market for 40 years. But the floor is still tiled in black and white, the walls covered in porcelain-enameled tin sheets. When the artist Robert Kobayashi, known as Kobi, bought Moes and the rest of its building in 1977, he moved in with his wife, the photographer Kate Keller, and installed his studio in the storefront, leaving the walls intact. As a sculptor who worked with tin, maybe he felt an affinity for the sheet metal. Maybe he just appreciated the history.

title: BAE Systems to Cut Almost 2,000 Jobs in Britain
description: LONDON  The British defense contractor BAE Systems said on Tuesday that it would cut nearly 2,000 jobs and reorganize its management structure in an effort to reshape its business and to cut costs as orders slow for military jets.

title: 10 French Novels to Read Now
description: PANTIN, France  France, or, rather, the French language, since not all authors who write in French hail from France, is the guest of honor at this years Frankfurt Book Fair, which runs from Oct. 11 to 15. To get a feel for the current state of Frances literary landscape, here are 10 recent novels by some of the most talked-about members of the 105-author French delegation to the Frankfurt Book Fair whose work has been translated into English.

title: North Korean Hackers Stole U.S.-South Korean Military Plans, Lawmaker Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korean hackers stole a vast cache of data, including classified wartime contingency plans jointly drawn by the United States and South Korea, when they breached the computer network of the South Korean military last year, a South Korean lawmaker said Tuesday.

title: Virtual Vandalism: Jeff Koonss Balloon Dog Is Graffiti-Bombed
description: Who gets to control augmented reality?

title: Raila Odinga, Kenya Opposition Leader, Wont Run in New Election
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  What appeared to be a historic step forward for democracy in Africa was thrown into turmoil on Tuesday when an opposition leader said he would not participate in a redo of Kenyas presidential election.

title: HelloFresh, the Meal Delivery Service, Pursues I.P.O. in Frankfurt
description: LONDON  HelloFresh, the German meal delivery company, said on Tuesday that it planned to raise up to $352 million in an initial public offering in Frankfurt.

title: Soldier Dances, From a Land Pervaded by the Military
description: One of the first things visitors to Israel notice is the soldiers. Theyre everywhere. Some are on duty, but others are slouched over coffee at a cafe, napping on a bus or just glued to their phones like everyone else. It can seem a peculiarly casual presence, but the ubiquity reflects how the military pervades all aspects of Israeli life. Reflecting on his career, the choreographer and performer Yossi Berg realized that its presence had infiltrated his dance work, too.

title: For Trump, the Reality Show Has Never Ended
description: WASHINGTON  Over the weekend, President Trump was accused by a Republican senator of running the White House like a reality show. In the 48 hours that followed, this is how the president rebutted the characterization.

title: Procter & Gamble Declares Victory in Proxy Battle; Peltz Says, Not So Fast
description: The largest and most expensive corporate proxy battle in history ended with a big question mark.

title: California Fires Lay Waste to 140,000 Acres and Rage On
description: NAPA, Calif.  With roads still blocked by the police and fires still raging across broad swaths of Northern California, Matt Lenzi hiked through smoke-choked vineyards and waded the Napa River to reach the home his father lived in for 53 years. In its place, he found only blackened debris, blackened earth, and ash.

title: Lil Mama Instructs Us on How to Glow Up Properly
description: Over the past year, Niatia Kirkland, the rapper and actress known as Lil Mama, hit a reset in life and on social media. Discarding her rap alias, she now goes by her given name.

title: 10% of New York City Public School Students Were Homeless Last Year
description: The number of homeless students in the New York City public school system rose again last year, according to state data released on Tuesday. The increase pushed the city over a sober milestone: One in every 10 public school students was homeless at some point during the 2016-17 school year.

title: Public Kitchen
description: The chef Jean-Georges Vongerichtens new Lower East Side restaurant offers the promise of the food of New York.

title: Lost in New York at Public Kitchen
description: At Jean-Georges Vongerichtens latest restaurant, Public Kitchen, the menu is supposed to have a theme: the food of New York City. Nobody I brought there noticed it, though. Somehow it slipped my mind, too, even though Id read about it weeks before my first meal, and had eaten things like smoked salmon and Manhattan clam chowder.

title: On the (Rising) Trail of Thai Food in America
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Crunchy hearts of palm and giant shrimp stir-fried with holy basil and the perfect ration of red chiles. A green papaya salad, freshly shredded and mashed with an extra portion of tiny Thai limes.

title: Why Big Cities Thrive, and Smaller Ones Are Being Left Behind
description: You dont want to be hit by a recession in a city like Steubenville, Ohio.

title: Malala Yousafzai, Nobel Peace Prize Laureate, Starts at Oxford
description: Malala Yousafzai, the 20-year-old Pakistani activist who was shot by the Taliban for advocating girls education, began her studies at the University of Oxford this week.

title: What Is the Clean Power Plan, and How Can Trump Repeal It?
description: Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, said Monday that he would issue a formal proposal to repeal the Clean Power Plan, a regulation on power plants that would have reduced domestic demand for coal and curbed the countrys planet-warming emissions.

description: $3.2 MILLION
