description: Helen Levitt, who apprenticed with Walker Evans in the subways, learned a thing or two about clandestine portraits.

title: Treat for a Bus Driver
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Subway Portraits of Helen Levitt
description: Theres no shortage of images from New York Citys subway system, with millions of smartphone-toting riders each day. Yet for much of the last century, until 1994, photography in the citys rapid transit system was illegal (though it was a spottily enforced offense). In the late 1930s  soon after the city imposed its ban  Helen Levitt, a young Bensonhurst native, apprenticed with Walker Evans as he photographed unsuspecting commuters.

title: Trumps Attacks on the Press: Telling Escalation From Empty Threats
description: President Trump usually ignores the criticism that comes his way from MSNBC, the reliably liberal cable channel that, his advisers argue, will attack his administration no matter what.

title: Full Video: Times Journalists Discuss the Challenges of Covering Trump's White House
description: Dean Baquet, the executive editor of The New York Times, joins the White House correspondents Maggie Haberman and Peter Baker in a TimesTalk about covering President Trump. The Timess media columnist, Jim Rutenberg, will moderate.

title: Let Them Eat Paper Towels
description: The situation in Iowa remains horrifying. More than a third of the population has been without clean water for three weeks, and waterborne diseases appear to be spreading. Only a sixth of the population has electricity. The health care system is a shambles, and sheer hunger may be a problem in some remote areas.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected)
description: Noah Baumbach narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Ben Stiller and Dustin Hoffman.

title: Congress Shouldnt Let Mr. Trump Kill Obamacare on His Own
description: This editorial has been updated to reflect news developments.

title: Noah Baumbach Narrates a Scene From The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected)
description: A father-son lunch turns into an uncomfortable negotiation in this scene from The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected). The scene features Ben Stiller as Matthew meeting his dad, Harold (Dustin Hoffman), for lunch, with a secret plan to bring up the business of trying to settle his fathers estate. He brings along an associate, Gabe (Matthew Shear), and Harold doesnt take the meeting so well. Mr. Baumbach shot the scene at a Brooklyn restaurant, where he and his crew capture much of the scene in a long take. In a recent interview in New York, the director discussed how he chose the location for the scene and what made it a challenge. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

title: How Facebooks Ad System Works
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In early September, Facebook revealed that it had identified about $100,000 in ads purchased on its social network by a Russian company linked to the Kremlin. Distributed between June 2015 and May of this year, the more than 3,000 ads added to evidence that Russia interfered with the 2016 presidential election.

title: What Would Happen if the U.S. Withdrew From Nafta
description: President Trump continues threatening to withdraw the United States from the North American Free Trade Agreement, and with negotiations on rocky ground, that risk could soon become reality. Withdrawing from the pact would bring big changes for the economy and for consumers.

title: We Brought Charles Murray to Campus. Guess What Happened.
description: Last night the social scientist Charles Murray came to the University of Michigan. Guess what happened next?

title: What We Know About Trumps Twin Blows to Obamacare
description: President Trump signed an executive order on Thursday morning that he said would begin saving the American people from the nightmare of Obamacare. On Thursday evening, he announced he would stop making scheduled payments to insurance companies that help them lower deductibles for low-income customers. Theres a lot thats still uncertain about how the two actions will change the health law. Heres what we know so far.

title: Joel Embiid Is Raring to Go, Which Is Both Good and Bad for the 76ers
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Before the Philadelphia 76ers played the Brooklyn Nets in a preseason game at Nassau Coliseum on Wednesday night, Brett Brown told Joel Embiid to cool it.

title: Venezuelas Government Cancels Another Gustavo Dudamel Tour
description: The conductor Gustavo Dudamel may well be Venezuelas most acclaimed cultural export, and the Simn Bolvar Symphony Orchestra of Venezuela has come to symbolize that nations commitment to social programs and music education for all.

title: House Ethics Office Says New York Congressman May Have Violated Rules
description: Representative Chris Collins of New York may have violated federal law by sharing nonpublic information about a company on whose board he served, according to a report released Thursday by the Office of Congressional Ethics.

title: Uber, Surging Outside Manhattan, Tops Taxis in New York City
description: Taxi or Uber?

title: Prosecutors Say Chelsea Bombing Suspect Had Evil in His Heart
description: In more than two hours of closing arguments on Thursday, a federal prosecutor traced one mans journey from reading about jihad in 2012 to buying and building explosive devices four years later, and his solitary walk through the streets of Manhattan one night last year, lugging bags laden with bombs, setting one on a sidewalk even as the boom of another sounded in his wake.

title: Google Unveils Job Training Initiative With $1 Billion Pledge
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google unveiled an initiative on Thursday to help train Americans for jobs in technology and committed to donating $1 billion over the next five years to nonprofits in education and professional training.

title: Unions Sue to Block Watered Down Rules for Charter Teacher Training
description: A fight over charter schools and teacher training escalated on Thursday when the city and state teachers unions filed a lawsuit in state court seeking to prevent new rules from going into effect that allow some charters to certify their own teachers.

title: Reversing Course, Cuomo Will Return Weinsteins Money
description: ALBANY  In the wake of widening revelations of sexual harassment and assault by Harvey Weinstein, a roster of the nations biggest Democrats immediately pledged to return campaign contributions or donate them to charity.

title: Trumps Chief of Staff, Speaking With Press, Walks a Verbal Tightrope
description: WASHINGTON  In his first extended appearance before the White House press corps on Thursday, John F. Kelly, the former Marine general turned presidents chief of staff, came off as very un-Trumpian.

title: Police in New York and London Look Into Assault Allegations Against Weinstein
description: The police in London and New York said Thursday that they were looking into complaints involving the disgraced film producer Harvey Weinstein, the latest turn in a scandal that has consumed Hollywood over allegations of sexual abuse and harassment.

title: At 91 and 100, a Couple Always Together, Until a Fatal Home Invasion
description: Ethlin Thompson loved to tell her neighbors the story of the time, about three decades ago, when she stood at a Brooklyn bus stop and prayed to God to send her a man. She was nearly 70. It seemed, perhaps, she needed a miracle.

title: Maduro Becomes Latest Leader Accused in Huge Bribery Scheme
description: MEDELLN, Colombia  President Nicols Maduro of Venezuela received at least $35 million in bribes from a Brazilian construction company in 2013, according to a video posted on a blog run by the countrys former attorney general, who fled the country in August.

title: Richard Bransons Virgin and Hyperloop One Transit Pods Become Fast Friends
description: High-speed hyperloop transit  the futuristic concept involving passenger pods that could zip from, say, San Francisco to Los Angeles in a half-hour  just got a boost from Richard Branson.

title: Amazon Studios Chief Suspended After Sexual Harassment Claim
description: Roy Price, the executive in charge of Amazons growing investment in movies and television shows, was suspended by the company on Thursday after a Hollywood producer publicly accused him of making unwanted sexual advances toward her.

title: California Fires Leave 32 Dead, a Vast Landscape Charred, and a Sky Full of Soot
description: SONOMA, Calif.  Some of the worst wildfires ever to tear through California have killed 32 people and torched a vast area of the states north this week, but the reach of the blazes is spreading dramatically further by the day, as thick plumes of smoke blow through population centers across the Bay Area.

title: Amid Yankees Jubilation, Relief for Joe Girardi and Aaron Judge
description: HOUSTON  It was early Thursday morning in the Yankees clubhouse, and the players were in the middle of their third celebration in the past two weeks. The first two came after the Yankees clinched a playoff berth and then won the American League wild-card game, but neither accomplishment was as dramatic as what they had just achieved  a comeback from a two-game deficit to conquer the Cleveland Indians in a division series.

title: New York City Will Miss a Deadline to Accommodate 5 New Charter Schools
description: New York Citys Department of Education said on Thursday that it would not find space for five new middle schools proposed by the Success Academy charter school network in time for the locations to be approved by a city panel in November.

title: Gunshots, a Cry of Kill the Hostages, Then Freedom for Canadian-American Family
description: WASHINGTON  Stuffed by their captors into the back of a car with their children as they were being ferried across the rugged tribal areas of northwest Pakistan, an American woman and her Canadian husband were in the final moments of their five-year ordeal as hostages.

title: A Disaster in the White House for Puerto Rico
description: Americans have gotten into the uneasy habit of wondering how low President Trump might go each day in his multiple tirades against those he imagines as enemies, critics and easy targets. But did he really have to pick on the storm-ravaged American citizens of Puerto Rico, of all defenseless people, and reveal such a cold-hearted lack of empathy for their plight?

title: Jeremy the Lefty Snail Is Dead. His Offspring Are All Right.
description: Lets have a moment of silence for Jeremy, the lefty brown garden snail, found dead Wednesday in a refrigerator in a British research lab. Jeremy was a rare snail, with an unusual shell that made him stand out among other garden snails. He will be missed.

title: 2 North Carolina Prison Workers Killed in Fiery Escape Attempt
description: Two prison employees were killed and 14 other people injured on Thursday when inmates at the Pasquotank Correctional Institution in North Carolina tried to escape, officials said.

title: Indian Court Chooses Clean Air Over Fireworks for a Festival
description: NEW DELHI  For generations, millions of Indians here in the capital have celebrated Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, by setting off a symphony of fireworks.

title: Review: Springsteen on Broadway Reveals the Artist, Real and Intense
description: There came a moment the other night, near the end of Bruce Springsteens overwhelming and uncategorizable Broadway show, when it seemed possible to see straight through his many masks to some core truth of his being.

title: Quotation of the Day: In Unity Deal, Respite for Gaza and Optimism for Palestinians
description: We do not want the flags of Fatah and Hamas, only the Palestinian flag.

title: Big Name in Home Security Systems
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  People dont believe me when I tell them that there is always a way into a puzzle, even the late week ones, but its true. What seems to happen is that some solvers quickly scan the list of clues on, say, a Friday puzzle,, see nothing that they know on the first pass, and decide that they cant solve it. Many times, they give up and walk away.

title: To Court Workers, Japanese Firms Try Being More Gay-Friendly
description: TOKYO  Once a week, the Japanese insurance company where Shunsuke Nakamura works tries to enliven its morning staff meeting by having employees give personal presentations. The topics tend to be mostly innocuous: hobbies, pets or wine recommendations.

title: Still Processing: Harvey Weinstein and Our Unreal Reality
description: Its our season finale! Weve spent our second season keeping a critical eye on the unreality of America and dissecting the systems of power that uphold the status quo. Last week, a series of news articles reported that Harvey Weinstein, one of the most powerful movie producers in Hollywood, has been accused of sexually harrassing women for decades. Twitter is ablaze with other women and men sharing their own stories of sexual misconduct at the hands of the powerful, spawning conversations about power and fame, privilege and punishment. The aftermath has raised questions about the commonality of harassment  and has forced us to confront our own complacency. We were compelled to talk about the cultural petri dish that allows assault and abuse to perpetuate and about what might be changing, socially and technologically, that is encouraging survivors to come forward. We also discuss the recently released Blade Runner 2049 which somehow felt lacking, as if science fiction cant keep up with the reality of the moment were living through. And before we sign off for a few months, we relive some of our favorite moments from this season. Thank you for listening, and well talk to you soon!

description: On the corner of my lawyers desk was a red button marked No. It was the type you might find in a display of gag gifts, next to the Whoopee cushions and boxing nun action figures.

description: MILAN  A.C. Milans museum sits on the ground floor of the clubs gleaming administrative headquarters, Casa Milan, in a smart district to the north of the city. It is a place of pilgrimage for hundreds of fans before most home games.

title: Right and Left React to Harvey Weinstein Reports
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: Should the Boy Scouts Be Coed?
description: Are you or have you ever been a part of a single-sex club, team, organization or school? If so, what did you like or dislike about it? What did you learn from it? How did that experience compare with being in a coed setting?

title: Teaching Activities for: Why Are More American Teenagers Than Ever Suffering From Severe Anxiety?
description: Before reading the article:

title: Put Women in Charge
description: Most women I know  and probably most women you know  have stories about sexual harassment. Mine happened in college, with a professor who was older than my father and who made me think he was genuinely interested in my writing. One day in his office, he told me he wanted to kiss and molest me. I muttered something about having a boyfriend and fled.

title: We Used to Build Things
description: They say that fighting a wildfire is the closest thing to being in combat. The trees explode, the wind whips down while the oxygen disappears and the fire sheets along the ground, streaking sideways like rushing waters.

title: The G.O.P. Is a Mess. Its Not All Trumps Fault.
description: If the modern Republican Party can be said to stand for anything, it is tax relief. Yet as the Republican effort to write and pass tax legislation develops, it looks increasingly possible  and perhaps even likely  that it, like the health care overhaul attempt that preceded it, will end in failure and disappointment.

title: Gun Carnage Is a Public Health Crisis
description: Well be talking about gun laws as time goes by, President Trump promised all too casually after the Las Vegas gunman took 58 lives in a rapid-fire slaughter. Time is indeed going by, and the silence is alarming as the Republican Congress and Mr. Trump, the devoted candidate of the National Rifle Association, duck their responsibility to confront the public health crisis of gun deaths.

title: The Guggenheim Surrenders on Free Expression
description: It was no surprise that some people were upset by a few works involving animals in the Guggenheim Museums new show, Art and China After 1989. What was surprising  and in our view badly mistaken  was the Guggenheims hasty, thinly justified decision to then censor its own show.

title: Trumps Sellout of American Heritage
description: The last runs of heavenly wild salmon are trickling in this month, the buttery coho with flesh the color of fall foliage. After that, well have to settle for mostly farmed and frozen fish until next spring  no substitute for the real deal.

description: AKATA WARRIOR By Nnedi Okorafor 496 pp. Viking. $18.99.

title: The Ghost That Haunts Grants Memoirs
description: Memoir in America is an atrocity arms race, Calvin Trillin writes. He describes it as a contest to reveal the most appalling family secret. That overstates things a bit, but he has a point. The genre flung open one of the first windows in our culture of self-exposure, well before social media arrived and took down the last curtains.

title: Tom Hanks: By the Book
description: Tom Hanks, the actor, producer, director and author of a new story collection, Uncommon Type, has no desire to read novels of murder and conspiracy.

title: The Latest in Crime Novels: Bad Mothers, Bad Memories and Bad Sex Toys
description: The most unnerving thing about Ali Lands debut novel, GOOD ME BAD ME (Flatiron, $25.99), is that you can trust the word of Annie Thompson, the 15-year-old narrator, because shes speaking to the mother she loves and misses. The anguished conversation is one-sided because her mother is about to go on trial for killing nine little boys  and Annie is the one who turned her in.

title: A Lamentation for a Life Cut Short
description: CUZ Or the Life and Times of Michael A. By Danielle Allen  Illustrated. 243 pp. Liveright Publishing. $24.95.

title: The Latest, Troubling Chapter in Feminist Dystopian Fiction
description: GATHER THE DAUGHTERS By Jennie Melamed 341 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $26.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Getting the Most Out of Cash-Back Rewards
description: Kenny writes: My wife and I recently consolidated our bank accounts. Id like us to use the credit card for all possible purchases because we get cash-back rewards. But my wife prefers the debit card  which offers no rewards  only because its been in her wallet for 10 years. Please order her to use the credit card.

title: Wringing Cash From Life Insurance
description: Were going to go through a quick, ten- to 15-minute personal health assessment, said Jay Jackson, vice president of Abacus Life Settlements in Orlando. There are no right or wrong answers.

title: Paperback Row
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: How to Pawn Valuables
description: Think of us as a bank of last resort, says Lou Tansky, the owner of Uncle Bens Pawn Shop in Cleveland. To pawn something, you must be an adult with valid identification, and the item must have some value as collateral. You dont need good credit, income or a bank account. Commonly pawned items include jewelry, electronics, musical instruments and firearms, but the possibilities are wide-ranging: Tansky has accepted a pocketknife and knows a broker who was approached about pawning a Learjet. Be aware of state-specific prohibitions; in Delaware, for example, it is illegal to pawn artificial limbs and wheelchairs. I dont want anybodys stuff, Tansky says. Most brokers make the bulk of their income from interest, not from reselling things.

title: Trump Disavows Nuclear Deal, but Doesnt Scrap It
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump announced on Friday his decision to disavow the Iran nuclear agreement, threatening to leave the deal altogether if it was not amended to permanently block Tehran from building nuclear weapons or intercontinental missiles.

title: Can Gowanus Survive Its Renaissance?
description: Welcome to Venice Jerko. The greeting is painted in three-foot-high letters on a brick wall along Brooklyns legendarily polluted Gowanus Canal, right across from the canals first luxury high-rise and its new waterfront promenade.

title: U.S. and Europe May Collide on Taxing Apple and Amazon
description: President Trump and congressional lawmakers are not the only ones interested in collecting taxes on global profits that American corporations are hoarding overseas. European regulators, knee deep in a campaign to stamp out tax avoidance, have their own plans for that money.

title: Behind the Cover: 10.15.17
description: Jake Silverstein, editor in chief: We dramatically cropped the portrait of Jillian, a teenager in Benoit Denizet-Lewiss article about adolescent anxiety, to make clear that she was meant to represent not just herself but all kids who suffer this way. We also liked the way that the weight of that heavy black rectangle looming above her seemed to nicely capture the sense of helplessness many of these teens feel.

title: A Chat With MacArthur Genius Nikole Hannah-Jones
description: On Wednesday, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation announced the 24 recipients of its annual fellowship, often called the genius grant, which awards $625,000, no strings attached, to exceptionally creative people each year. Among those who received the unexpected phone call this year was Nikole Hannah-Jones, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, whose work, rooted in deeply researched historical insight, focuses on endemic racism in housing and education.

title: Chargers Okung Issues Call to Action for N.F.L. Players
description: In an unusual and public call to arms, a Los Angeles Chargers lineman posted a letter on The Players Tribune on Friday morning urging the leagues 1,700 players to take a unified stand against pressure from N.F.L. team owners to curb demonstrations during the national anthem before games.

title: Senate Takes Step to Approve Drilling in Arctic Wildlife Refuge
description: Updated Nov. 15: A Senate committee on Wednesday voted to approve legislation that would open a portion of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas drilling, moving one step closer to achieving a priority for Alaska Republicans and other conservatives.

title: An Author and a Zoologist Team Up to Rescue the Worlds Endangered Species from Extinction
The Recovery Process: Caribbean Tourism, Island by Island
description: After an unforgiving start to the hurricane season, some idyllic Caribbean destinations are in the midst of a slow and arduous recovery that may take months, even years, while others are ready  or nearly ready  for the all-important holiday travel season.

title: Along the Mississippi
description: One Friday afternoon, we drove away from Chicago to look for rivers. The first one we came across was slender and manicured, like a path for floating golf carts. It followed the highway for a mile or two before turning away. Then came the real thing, the DuPage River, flowing fast and high with spring rain. We followed that for a while, heading toward our main destination: the Mississippi.

title: How a Seed Bank, Almost Lost in Syrias War, Could Help Feed a Warming Planet
description: TERBOL, Lebanon  Ali Shehadeh, a seed hunter, opened the folders with the greatest of care. Inside each was a carefully dried and pressed seed pod: a sweet clover from Egypt, a wild wheat found only in northern Syria, an ancient variety of bread wheat. He had thousands of these folders stacked neatly in a windowless office, a precious herbarium, containing seeds foraged from across the hot, arid and increasingly inhospitable region known as the Fertile Crescent, the birthplace of farming.

title: Howard Cheerleaders Add Voices to the Anthem Debate by Taking a Knee
description: WASHINGTON  A few minutes before kickoff on Oct. 7 at Howard Universitys Greene Stadium  about two miles from the White House  the public address announcer said, We ask that you please rise as we honor the United States of America. At the 50-yard-line, four members of the Air Force R.O.T.C. presented the colors.

title: What to Read Before You Go to Mississippi
description: The Mississippi River has been a muse for writers like Mark Twain and William Faulkner. Here, three contemporary writers explore the beauty, tragedy and humanity in the Mississippi River region.

title: New Sentences: From Dan Browns Origin: A Novel
description: Dan Browns new book product, Origin: A Novel, is more than 450 pages long, but I read only one sentence and had to stop. I set the book down and walked away slowly and decided to just wall off that part of the house and let the raccoons have it.

title: Poem: Dream-Clung, Gone
description: Selected by Terrance Hayes

title: The 10.1.17 Issue
description: RE: N.G.R.I.

title: This Is Not Arthur Laffers Famous Napkin
description: WASHINGTON  It is one of the iconic moments in modern economics: A young professor named Arthur Laffer sketched a curve on a bar napkin in 1974 to show an aide to President Gerald R. Ford why the federal government should cut taxes.

title: New York Real Estate, Warts and All
description: Fifth-floor walk-ups, brick-wall views, the N train underfoot and other quirks that make up the citys imperfect resale market.

title: The Most Common Obstacles to a Sale  and What to Do About Them
description: David Hawthornes NoHo apartment, with its 14-foot ceilings and striking brick walls, has New York in its bones.

title: Seth Meyers Cant Believe Trump Is Talking About Pulling Troops From Puerto Rico
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: Twitter Users Split on Boycott Over Platforms Move Against Rose McGowan
description: Activists, celebrities and journalists joined a boycott of Twitter on Friday to protest the social media platforms locking of the account of the actress Rose McGowan, a fierce critic of the film producer Harvey Weinstein over his alleged sexual harassment and assaults of women.

title: Teaching With: Rebuilding in Miniature
description: In this short documentary, Rebuilding in Miniature, an Iraqi refugee bides his time in immigration limbo by creating obsessively detailed dioramas. With his family still in Iraq and his own future uncertain, he escapes into his creative work and uses it as a positive motivator to move forward in life during such a difficult period.

title: Affordable Care Act, Puerto Rico, Chicago Cubs: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: BASF to Buy Bayer Units for $7 Billion
description: LONDON  The German chemicals giant Bayer said on Friday that it had agreed to sell parts of its crop science business to BASF for about $7 billion.

title: My Husbands Lover
description: Each time my husband returns to Pittsburgh from Mexico, I tell him he has that exquisite pueblo smell. It lingers on him for days. I cringe pointing this out: It seems a detail that belongs in the short story of a 19-year-old who has just spent a semester abroad  he smelled of wood smoke, leather and pine as he spun me around  but it is true. He grabs me and pulls me to him, takes a sensuous whiff of my hair: Mmmmm, he says. You smell like Target.

title: New York Today: Farewell to a Jeopardy! Favorite
description: Good morning on this Friday the 13th.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Flu, Anxiety and a Deadly Outbreak
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: She Met Her Prince (for Real!) at a D.C. Nightclub
description: Few love stories resemble a fairy tale as much as the courtship and marriage of Ariana Austin and Joel Makonnen. Of course, it helped that the groom is an actual prince and the bride has a prominent lineage of her own.

title: Trumps Obamacare Moves Will Deepen Health Inequality
description: This story was updated to reflect news developments.

title: Mayim Bialik: Being a Feminist in Harvey Weinsteins World
description: I entered the Hollywood machine in 1986 as a prominent-nosed, awkward, geeky, Jewish 11-year-old  basically a scrawnier version of the person I am today. Back then we didnt have the internet or social media or reality TV, but I didnt need any of that to understand that I didnt look or act like other girls in my industry, and that I was immersing myself in a business that rewarded physical beauty and sex appeal above all else.

title: Chinese Museum Pulls Exhibit Comparing Animals to Black People
description: HONG KONG  A museum in China this week removed a photography exhibit, which juxtaposed images of wild African animals with black African people, after complaints that the display was racist.

title: Bryan Roberts of Venrock on Seeing Problems as Opportunities
description: This interview with Bryan Roberts, a partner at Venrock, a venture capital firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Jean Rollin and Lucio Fulci: Maestros of Horror
description: Theres never a bad time to watch a good horror movie. But the Halloween season gives just about everyone a good reason to binge on ghoulish films  and streaming video has lots of them. So this weeks and next weeks columns will deal with Halloween fare.

title: How Gbenga Akinnagbe, Actor and Activist, Spends His Sundays
description: The actor, activist and entrepreneur Gbenga Akinnagbe (BENG-ga a-KEEN-na-begh) can currently be seen playing a pimp in The Deuce, HBOs ode to Times Square in the 1970s and 80s. But he might be best recognized, still, for his work in another HBO series, The Wire, where he played the right-hand man to a vicious drug dealer in Baltimore. When Mr. Akinnagbe, 38, a child of Nigerian immigrants, is not on set or traveling, he is committed to his activism and businesses, preferring to work on them in and around his brownstone in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: Facebook Goes to Washington: DealBook Briefing
description: Will a public relations campaign in Washington by Facebooks Sheryl Sandberg and others take the heat off technology giants?

title: North Korea Renews Guam Threat Ahead of Joint Naval Exercise
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As the United States and South Korea prepare for next weeks joint naval exercise, North Korean officials on Friday renewed their threat to launch ballistic missiles near Guam, an American territory in the western Pacific.

title: Philippines Retreats From Threat to Expel E.U. Envoys
description: MANILA  The Philippines backed away on Friday from President Rodrigo Dutertes threat the day before to expel European ambassadors, his spokesman said, after apparently misunderstanding the source of criticism of his deadly drug crackdown.

title: How to Get Cortana to Keep Track of Your Favorite Teams
