title: Your Week in Culture: Jay-Z, Eugene ONeill and Princess Bride in Theaters Nationwide
description: New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts  its a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of Oct. 15, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:

title: Houstons Wortham Theater Center, Weeks After Harvey Struck
description: HOUSTON  After Tropical Storm Allison battered this city in 2001, the Wortham Theater Center  home to the Houston Grand Opera and the Houston Ballet  was fitted with precautionary storm doors to help reduce flooding in the future. Yet Hurricane Harvey proved too much for the buildings lower floors, as a tour in late September by journalists and photographers made clear.

title: Listen to The Daily: John F. Kelly, and Rohingya Atrocities
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: A Quick-Seared Fish That Sizzles and Satisfies
description: Making a fish dinner at home can be a bit of a splurge, given how expensive fresh seafood is. It would be a shame to overcook your hard-earned haul.

title: Kobe Steel Scandal Grows to Include Subsidiaries
description: TOKYO  A scandal about falsified quality data at Kobe Steel expanded on Friday, as the Japanese steel maker said nine subsidiaries, including several outside Japan, had either failed to carry out required product checks or lied about the results.

title: Senator Susan Collins Will Not Run for Governor of Maine
description: ROCKPORT, Me.  After months of open deliberation about her future, Senator Susan Collins of Maine announced Friday that she would not run for governor and would remain in the Senate.

title: California Today: Wildfire Photos Tell a Story of Ruin
description: Good morning.

title: Puerto Rico vs. Florida and Texas
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: Farhad and Nicoles Week in Tech: Russia, Russia Everywhere
description: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is off this week, so Nicole Perlroth, who covers cybersecurity, took his place.

title: Could a Perfect Tax Storm Strike Your Condo?
description: Death and taxes are unavoidable, but at least with taxes you expect to have a rough idea of what will be demanded. But buy an apartment in a new building and a year or two down the road, you might find yourself staring at a tax bill that looks pretty different from the number tossed around at the open house.

title: Trump: Well Be There for Puerto Rico, a Day After Critical Messages
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump sought to reassure Puerto Rico on Friday that he was not abandoning the hurricane-ravaged island, shifting his message a day after blaming its leadership for the territorys ongoing crisis and warning that he "cannot keep federal troops and emergency workers in P.R. forever.

title: Trump Is Trying to Gut Obamacare. Heres Why His Plan May Fail.
description: President Trumps decision to stop paying subsidies to insurance companies that cover many low-income Americans is his most overt action so far to undermine the Obamacare markets, which reopen for sign-ups on Nov. 1.

title: Things Boys Could Learn at Girl Scouts
description: Encouraging girls to do things that boys have traditionally done, but not the other way around, can be detrimental to girls  but also to boys.

title: 8 Sleek Tape Dispensers for Your Desk
description: The most mundane office staple becomes an object of desire.

title: N.C.A.A.: North Carolina Will Not Be Punished for Academic Scandal
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  The N.C.A.A. did not dispute that the University of North Carolina was guilty of running one of the worst academic fraud schemes in college sports history, involving fake classes that enabled dozens of athletes to gain and maintain their eligibility.

title: Marijuana Crop Is Burning in the California Wildfires
description: Fatal fires that have consumed nearly 200,000 acres in Northern California, devastating the regions vineyards particularly in Napa and Sonoma Counties, are also taking a toll on a fledgling industry just months before its debut: recreational marijuana.

title: The Benefits (and the Catch) of Health Savings Accounts
description: Its benefits open enrollment season at many employers, and workers are increasingly likely to hear about an option, known as an H.S.A., that can help them pay for medical expenses and save money on their taxes.

title: China Seeks Small Stakes in, and More Sway Over, Online Firms
description: HONG KONG  Some ambitious Chinese online media companies have won backing from a very powerful investor: the Chinese government itself.

title: Ron Livingston Loves to Play the Jerk
description: The embezzling slacker in Office Space. The Post-it note breakup guy in Sex and the City. The creepy private investigator in Search Party. Ron Livingston has built a career on playing the jerk who just cant keep the impertinent thoughts percolating in his brain from spewing onto everyone in his path.

title: The Pioneering Modernist Who Wrote an Audacious String Quartet
description: In Europe one can work! the young composer Ruth Crawford declared with excitement. Traveling abroad on a Guggenheim fellowship  the first woman to receive one  she had arrived in Berlin in 1930 planning to write her first orchestral piece.

title: Whos Afraid of Goldberg Variations? Not This Choreographer.
description: Pam Tanowitz usually begins a dance when she has an idea for one. But her new premiere started differently: Simone Dinnerstein, an acclaimed pianist whose first love was dance, contacted her. They made a date for coffee.

title: Jay Pharoah on White Famous, Culture Gaps and His Grandmothers Meatloaf
description: LOS ANGELES  Canters Deli has welcomed plenty of celebrities over the years but Jay Pharoah was making his first visit as he sat down to breakfast one weekday morning in July.

title: A Biographer of Martin Luther Promotes Faith in the Face of Evil
description: GOTTA HAVE FAITH: Just in time for the Protestant Reformations 500th anniversary, Eric Metaxas biography Martin Luther hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 7. One of the books more familiar theses is the extent to which mass media (in the form of the printing press) and populism (in the form of a German-language Bible) helped to spread the Reformations ideas; had Luther lived today, its not hard to imagine him behind a talk radio microphone.

title: European Leaders Criticize Trumps Disavowal of Iran Deal
description: LONDON  Iran, Russia and European leaders roundly condemned President Trumps decision on Friday to disavow the Iran nuclear deal, saying that it reflected the growing isolation of the United States, threatened to destabilize the Middle East and could make it harder to resolve the growing tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

title: On Harvey Weinstein
description: Sexual harassment allegations uncovered by The Times stretch over nearly three decades.

title: Defendant in Londons Parsons Green Attack to Go on Trial on March 5
description: LONDON  The trial of Ahmed Hassan Mohammed Ali, an 18-year-old Iraqi orphan charged with attempted murder in connection with a terrorist attack at a London Underground station last month, will begin on March 5, according to British news reports on Friday.

title: Richard Thaler Talks About Silly (but Serious) Things
description: Richard H. Thaler learned early on Monday that he had won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for contributions to behavioral economicsa field that he helped create.

title: LuPone Surgery Forces War Paint to Announce Early Closing
description: The Broadway musical War Paint has changed its closing date to Nov. 5 so that Patti LuPone can undergo immediate hip replacement surgery. The show was scheduled to run until Dec. 30.

title: The Times Issues Social Media Guidelines for the Newsroom
description: This article was originally published on Oct. 13, 2017, and was updated on Nov. 3, 2020, to reflect new guidance around Twitters conversation settings and the use of muting and blocking on social media.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

title: Not Shying Away From Horror
description: We all know the clich: The teenage girl suffers through a horror movie, while cowering behind her boyfriend. The equally frightened girl onscreen takes a sinister phone call from the slasher who is terrorizing an otherwise bucolic town.

title: Beyond the Scream: What I Learned From Horror Movies
description: Growing up as a black kid in Chicago, my idea of scary was a quiet street in suburbia.

title: Sunil Gulati Says He Wont Resign as President of U.S. Soccer
description: Yes, Sunil Gulati, the president of U.S. Soccer, said, he understood American soccer fans were angry and frustrated  infuriated, really  at the United States mens national teams failure to qualify for next summers World Cup. Yes, he admitted, he was personally disappointed, too. And yes, he confirmed, Bruce Arena had quit as the teams coach Friday morning in the wake of that elimination.

title: Shania Twain Was Countrys Crossover Queen. What Is She Now?
description: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

title: Boom Time in Nollywood
description: Emily Witt spent five weeks in Nigeria to research Nollywood, her new book about the countrys thriving film industry.

title: Make T Something | Alex Da Corte
description: The artist accepts T's challenge to make an object in under an hour using a select few items  including a copy of The New York Times  with spooky results.

title: Why Frankensteins Monster Haunts Queer Art
description: I HAVE FOUND IT! Mary Shelley remembered thinking when she awoke from a fateful nightmare in the summer of 1816 with a thunderclap of inspiration. What terrified me will terrify others. These terrors provided the raw material for Frankenstein, which she composed at 19 and published anonymously in London two years later, unleashing one of the great ogres of the imagination into the world. I saw the hideous phantasm of a man stretched out, she wrote, and then, on the working of some powerful engine, show signs of life. To quote the mad doctor responsible for him in the 1931 Universal Pictures film: Its alive! Now, as the 200th birthday of Shelleys Monster  or, really, her monstrous allegory  fast approaches, he remains at large.

title: On Long Island, Officials Plead for Help in Stopping MS-13
description: Maria Elena Yanes and her son Ezequiel escaped Honduras after members of the MS-13 gang burst into their home with weapons to force him to join. He was 10 years old.

title: Sculpture Too Sexual for the Louvre to Be Shown at Pompidou Center
description: After the Louvre demurred, an art installation many consider to be sexually explicit will instead be displayed outside the Pompidou Center in Paris.

title: Trump Names Former Texas Regulator as White House Environmental Adviser
description: President Trump has nominated a former top Texas environmental regulator, who has argued that carbon dioxide is a harmless gas that should not be regulated, to be the White House senior adviser on environmental policy.

title: Xi Jinping and Chinas New Era of Glory
description: BEIJING  Two weeks after taking Chinas top office in November 2012, Xi Jinping took part in what seemed like a throwaway photo op. He took his top lieutenants to the newly renovated National Museum of China, a vast hall stuffed with relics of Chinas glorious past: terra-cotta soldiers from Xian, glazed statues from the Tang dynasty and rare bronzes from the distant Shang dynasty.

title: London Auctions Are on the Rise, but a Big Failure Casts a Shadow
description: Sales of contemporary art have returned to a growth path, the auction result database artprice.com said in a report published on Oct. 2. According to the report, after two years of healthy correction, global auction turnover of contemporary art grew 14 percent in the first half of 2017, signaling a new period of prosperity.

title: An Appetizer So Good It Should Be Dinner
description: When youre invited to a friends house for dinner, its impolite to gobble so many of the hors doeuvres that you have no room for the rest of the meal.

title: Seven Takeaways From the Times Journalists Who Cover Trump
description: On Oct. 12, Dean Baquet, The Timess executive editor, joined Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman, two White House correspondents, to discuss the challenges of covering the Trump administration. Jim Rutenberg, The Timess media columnist, moderated the TimesTalk panel, which was streamed live online.

title: Stream These 9 Underappreciated TV Shows on Hulu
description: Thanks to The Handmaids Tale, which last year became the first streaming-service original series to win an Emmy for best drama, some of you may be subscribing to Hulu for the first time and wondering how to get your moneys worth (and if youre still not sure whether to subscribe, heres our guide to the streaming service.) Much of Hulus TV content consists of current, widely seen shows, but the streaming service has also licensed a handful of old and new series  in a variety of genres  that even dedicated telephiles may have missed. Here are a handful worth digging into:

title: An Our Town Image as Sturdy as a Chair
description: If youve walked just about anywhere in New York City, youve seen the work of Paula Scher. A partner in the design firm Pentagram, Ms. Scher is the creative hand behind some of the most recognizable graphic identities that dot the city, including logos (Citibank, Shake Shack), poster art (Public Theater) and organizational branding (New York City Ballet).

title: The Fine Art of Tuning a Corvettes Sound
description: Charlie Rusher, 31, is a noise and vibration engineer at Chevrolet in Milford, Mich.

title: Tired of Twee Edison Bulbs? Bring On the Neon
description: Last year, Coach, the handbag and accessories company, hired Lite Brite Neon Studio to create a six-foot-tall pink Tyrannosaurus Rex for its store in the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan.

title: Austria Is Poised to Shift Sharply Right in Election
description: VIENNA  Austrians rejected a right-wing populist to represent them as head of state by a wafer-thin margin last year. But after a general campaign focused on immigration and rocked by scandal, voters appear poised in elections this Sunday to give populism a new push by granting a far-right party at least a share of power in the next government.

title: How Funds Manage Boatloads of Money
description: Fund providers are paid a percentage of the assets they hold as a management fee, so managing more assets is better for them. But is it better for you, the shareholder?

title: Focused Bets on Growth Propel Three Stock Funds
description: The managers of three of the third quarters better-performing mutual funds thrived by betting on growth: They all favored companies that have been increasing their earnings at faster-than-average rates.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: New York is still behind the curve in terms of familiarity with the explosion of contemporary art in China between the 1989 Tiananmen massacre and the 2008 Beijing Olympics. This survey, through Jan 7, 2018, reprises much of what we know, but also discusses large group projects and shifts the focus from auction-favored painting onto Conceptualism. (Above, Chen Zhens Fu Dao/Fu Dao, Upside-Down Buddha/Arrival at Good Fortune.)After animal-rights protests, three works are in altered form. HOLLAND COTTER

title: During Storms, Most Animals Take Shelter. But Some Birds Take Flight.
description: Q. When the recent hurricanes hit, how did animals seek refuge?

title: Earthquakes! Fires! Shootings! Storms! How Tech Can Help Ease Disaster Fatigue
description: One of the first things I do every morning when I wake up is check the latest news on my smartphone. In the last few weeks alone, that means  like so many other people  Ive started the day with some of the most horrific news imaginable: a mass shooting, devastating storms, terrible wildfires. Its taken a toll on my overall well-being  and very likely yours, too.

title: Investing by Betting on the Sponsors of Sports
description: Jim Kozimor, a sportscaster for NBC in the San Francisco Bay Area, has long marveled over the wealth of the teams and leagues he has covered.

title: Tallyho! A Suburban Fox Hunt Endures
description: NORTH SALEM, N.Y.  The red-coated masters of the Goldens Bridge Hounds sat high on horseback surrounded by a pack of hyperactive hounds. They were all poised to head out on a fox hunt in the still-misty fields in this affluent town in northern Westchester County.

title: A Blueprint for Womens Sports Success. But Can It Be Copied?
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Its easy to know when its game day at Providence Park.

title: An Old-School Investment Manager That Builds Wealth Quietly
description: San Francisco  In the hard-sell world of mutual funds, the art of pushing pricey investments is a source of pride for many executives.

title: Whats New on Netflix and Amazon Prime This Weekend
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

title: Ron Chernow on Grant
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: After a Turkish Prison, the Potent Symbol of a Lingering Kiss
description: ISTANBUL  When he was released from prison after midnight late last month, Kadri Gursel walked straight to his wife, Nazire, and embraced her. Their lingering kiss in front of the prison, and a soldiers shy glancing away, was caught on camera by a Turkish photographer and sent round the world.

title: Funds That Can Put Your Investments on a Low-Carbon Diet
description: If you care about climate change, your money can help shrink your carbon footprint. You can buy appliances that are more energy efficient or a hybrid or electric car  or, better yet, a bike. You can install thicker insulation in your home or solar panels on your roof.

title: Algae in Lake Erie: What Can Be Done?
description: To the Editor:

title: How Did Wolves Become Dogs?
description: Scientists arent entirely sure how wolves evolved into dogs, but new research into the genetic and social behavior of wolf pups may offer some clues.

title: Wolf Puppies Are Adorable. Then Comes the Call of the Wild.
description: NICOLET, Quebec  Im sitting in an outdoor pen with four puppies chewing my fingers, biting my hat and hair, peeing all over me in their excitement.

title: Where Do All the Disgraced C.E.O.s Go?
description: Its become a ritual of corporate life: Trouble comes, and the chief executive walks the plank. These days, though, so many companies are embroiled in scandals that we need a wider plank.

title: The Stock Market Charges Ahead, Despite the Worlds Storms
description: Hurricanes in North America, earthquakes in Latin America, tensions on the Korean Peninsula and political turbulence in the United States, Germany and Spain have produced little but shrugs on Wall Street.

title: In Early Results, Shorter Treatment for Tuberculosis Proves Effective
description: Taking the right antibiotics for just nine months may be as effective against drug-resistant tuberculosis as taking them for two years, as is currently recommended, according to preliminary findings from an international study.

title: The Playlist: Mavis Staples Warns of Deadly Force, and 9 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, a song from Becks new album, Colors; an international throwdown from Major Lazer (and guests); and a blippy tune from Kailee Morgue.

title: Femme Fatale, Fallen Woman, Spy: Looking for the Real Mata Hari
description: LEEUWARDEN, the Netherlands  In December 1915, Margaretha Zelle, the woman known to all the world as the exotic dancer Mata Hari, was traveling by ship from one of her lovers in Paris to another in The Hague. The international sex symbol was famous for provocative routines in a nude body stocking with a bejeweled bra and golden headdress. Sometimes she would tell people she was a Javanese princess or the daughter of an Indian temple dancer, but only rarely would she reveal that she was Dutch.

title: Review: Leif Ove Andsnes Blazes Out a Rachmaninoff Rarity
description: Rachmaninoffs Second and Third Piano Concertos have long been staples of the repertory. And his First Concerto, though less often played, is youthful and appealing.

title: Have You Tried to Contact Us? Let Us Know How Were Doing
description: The Reader Center is a newsroom initiative that is helping The Times build deeper ties with our audience.

title: A Cubs Fan Admits: Were No Longer the Lovable Losers
description: After decades of self-flagellation, it is not easy ceding the mantle of martyrdom to more deserving baseball fans. But this Chicago Cubs rooter is now prepared for the long overdue transfer of perpetual suffering to other enthusiasts.

title: Psychiatric Evaluation of Benjamin Paddock
description: F.B.I. profilers are trying to construct a psychological autopsy of Stephen Paddock, the Las Vegas gunman. One of the most telling documents might be a yellowed, four-page psychiatric evaluation from 1960 about Mr. Paddock's father.

title: An Arrow Fell From the Sky and Disrupted a Cricket League
description: A dispute over relegation and a last-ditch appeal: The story might come up in almost any sports league around the world. But few sports controversies begin with a mysterious crossbow arrow perilously sailing into a cricket stadium from out of the sky.

title: Fathers History Could Offer Insight Into Mind of Las Vegas Gunman
description: Facing prison for a string of bank robberies, Benjamin Hoskins Paddock beamed cheerfully at a psychiatrist evaluating his fitness to stand trial, and mused at length  at times with becoming modesty  about his life stealing cars, running cons, enduring solitary confinement and getting fired from a job as a bus driver after playing tag with the buses.

title: Dating an Older Guy
description: To the Editor:

title: At This Brooklyn Bar, Its Just You, Your Date and the Barman
description: Public drinking in New York can be a chore. Many of the citys bars are about as intimate as a rush-hour subway. Others serve as the stalking grounds for happy-hour predators. When the suits and ties arrive, it can be hard to find a stool or to get your glass refilled.

title: Zinke Vows to End Virus of Harassment in Park Service
description: WASHINGTON  Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke vowed Friday that there would be no quarter for employees who sexually harass or discriminate against colleagues. He said he would dismiss anyone found guilty of harassment and supervisors who sweep such charges under the rug.

title: Leonard Bernstein Turns 100
description: Galas were held last week for Carnegie Hall, the Rubin Museum of Art and the Carnegie Medal of Philanthropy.

title: Unlimited Passes in Hand, Retirees Make Off Peaking an Art Form
description: It takes Craig Miller just 30 minutes to get out the door on a powder day.

title: Friday Night Music: Moron Edition
description: Since what prompted Rex Tillerson was, reportedly, Trumps desire for a tenfold increase in Americas already civilization-destroying nuclear arsenal, the obvious:

title: Private Doors Swing Wide for Open House New York
description: New Yorkers may have a reputation for being unwelcoming, but on Saturday and Sunday more than 240 sites not normally available for public view will be accessible as part of the 15th annual Open House New York event.

title: In Californias Wine Country, Reckoning With an Inferno
description: Santa Rosa, Calif.  Just a week ago, talk in Sonomas wine country bemoaned the vagaries of Mother Nature. It was the finish to a difficult harvest, when record heat shriveled grapes and forced a mad scramble to salvage the crop.

title: Edward Lee Takes His Show to Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Louisville, Ky., was everything to Edward Lee. The Brooklyn-born chef moved to the city in 2003, after having visited only once for the Kentucky Derby. Since then, the city has given him his wife, a circle of friends and a unique culinary voice that brought TV gigs and corporate sponsorships.

title: Why Trump Hates the Iran Nuclear Deal
description: President Trump has called the Iran nuclear deal the worst deal ever. David E. Sanger, the national security correspondent for The Times, explains why the president is against the deal, and what that means for its future.

title: Leave the Butterflies Alone!
description: To the Editor:

title: Pani Puri: A Dribbly, Joyful Mess
description: LOS ANGELES  I grew up thinking my mom was the pinnacle of virtue. When I was young, she told me that she had lied only once (a lie in itself). The story of that lie was of mythic importance to our family: When my mother was a kid in Kolkata, India, there was a pani puri cart across the street from her house, but she wasnt allowed to eat from it in the afternoons for fear that shed ruin her appetite for dinner.

title: Equifaxs Grip on Mortgage Data Squeezes Smaller Rivals
description: Like it or not, when you apply for a home mortgage or to refinance an existing loan, Equifax will be a part of the process.

title: Addressing a Gender Pay Disconnect
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Spitfire Fiddling: The Weeks 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
description: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of whats moved and delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

title: Another Shift in Las Vegas Timeline Caps Days of Confusion
description: The Las Vegas police again revised the timeline of the Oct. 1 shooting at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, saying on Friday that Stephen Paddock shot and wounded a security guard on his hotel floor about the same time he began to spray bullets on a country music concert below.

title: A Civilian Corps for Disasters?
description: To the Editor:

title: Grapes, Sour or Sweet, Are Ripe for Dessert
description: The grapevine is one of the oldest plants in cultivation, and grapes are still the worlds largest fruit crop. Much of it goes into the rich and various world of winemaking. But, for all my delight in drinking wine, here Im writing about the grapes that I use in the kitchen.

title: Now That Girls May Join the Boy Scouts
description: To the Editor:

title: The Link Uniting Donors and Doers for Social Change
description: Stanley Druckenmiller, the hedge fund manager, wanted his charitable dollars to do more to reduce childhood poverty. He had been deeply involved with the Harlem Childrens Zone, which helps poor children and families in New York. But he said he wanted to do something to break the cycle of generational poverty, a goal seemingly beyond even a very wealthy person like himself.

title: Ending Health Subsidies: People Will Die
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion Breaks Its Silence on Harvey Weinstein Scandal
description: In the days since The New York Times broke the story of allegations of decades of harassment and assault by Harvey Weinstein, torrents of heart-wrenching stories have poured forth from at least 30 women who say they were victimized by Mr. Weinstein. So have unstinting condemnations from many who worked with Mr. Weinstein or benefited from their relationship with him, both in film and in Democratic political circles.

title: Jitters in Kirkuk Over Iraqi Troop Movements
description: BAGHDAD  Kurdish and Iraqi officials rushed Friday to calm fears of impending military action around the contested city of Kirkuk.

title: De Blasio Ad Focuses on Low Crime and Trump
description: With the mayoral election less than a month away, Mayor Bill de Blasio is riding a commanding lead in the polls and has about $2.3 million remaining in his campaign coffers. That is about twice the amount of his nearest opponent, Assemblywoman Nicole Malliotakis, a Republican who began advertising late last month.

title: Chinas Embrace of Private Investment Is Getting Tighter
description: Chinas president, Xi Jinping, wants to regain the private sectors confidence even as he squeezes it more tightly. Aligning private investment with state priorities could grease the bureaucratic skids for some companies, but more official meddling in boardrooms is unlikely to produce good business decisions. Opaque party politics will confuse outside investors and blur the line between some state and private companies.

title: What Were Reading: Harvey Weinstein
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: U.N. Officials Condemn Arrests of Gays in Azerbaijan, Egypt and Indonesia
description: GENEVA  United Nations officials on Friday condemned the recent mass arrests of gay and transgender people in Azerbaijan, Egypt and Indonesia, saying that the authorities in those countries had violated international law by detaining, mistreating and torturing them.

title: David vs. Goliath Gets an Update: Its Now Altuve vs. Judge
description: Jose Altuve is an outlier on the Houston Astros in many categories. Thats what happens when you are the front-runner for the Most Valuable Player Award in the American League. Altuve has the most hits, stolen bases and total bases on the team, and he leads in batting average and on-base-plus-slugging percentage, or OPS.

title: At a Tumultuous Moment, Unesco Picks a New Leader
description: PARIS  A former culture minister from France was elected on Friday to lead Unesco, the United Nations educational and cultural agency, a decision that was overshadowed by the Trump administrations decision a day earlier to withdraw the United States from the organization.

title: Eight Kitchen Gadgets on the Horizon
description: Some of the hits and misses from the Smart Kitchen Summit held this week in Seattle.

title: Kitchen of the Future: Smart and Fast but Not Much Fun
description: SEATTLE  Wandering among the engineers and strategy directors and managers of something called connected customer experience at the Smart Kitchen Summit, one had to wonder: Do any of these people actually cook?

title: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
description: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Bob Weinsteins Upbeat Statement Belies Company in Chaos
description: LOS ANGELES  As talk of a sale or shutdown swirled around the embattled Weinstein Company on Friday, the studios co-founder Bob Weinstein tried to paint a picture of stability, saying that business is continuing as usual and outlining plans for film releases through February.

title: Review: A Requiem Mass With a Southern Twang in Animal Wisdom
description: We who are gathered here tonight in an unconsecrated theater in Brooklyn have been asked to join in a holy invocation, beginning with Oh, Lord, as we raise cups filled with  not communion wine  but sacred Coca-Cola. Of course, if our faiths lean in other directions, we are told, we may substitute Oh, goddess, Oh, goodness or, if we believe in nothing, O.K.

title: Guantnamo Defendant Is Sentenced, in Rare Success for Military Commission
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  A panel of American military officers at the Guantnamo Bay wartime prison sentenced on Friday a Saudi detainee, Ahmed Muhammed Ahmed Haza al-Darbi, to 13 years in prison for his admitted role in a 2002 attack by Al Qaeda on a French oil tanker off the Yemeni coast.

title: 6 Things Ts Editors Like Right Now
description: Fancy candles have become so ubiquitous, they sometimes feel like unthoughtful gifts. This holiday season, I will instead be giving a new collection of soaks and salts from the natural beauty store Follain. For the product line, the shops founder Tara Foley worked with four of her favorite brands: The Follain x Farmaesthetics Dream Bath Elixir, a cloudy tonic with blue yarrow and eucalyptus essential oils, fosters deep breathing, while the lactic acid in Follain x RICAs milk bath of white clay and pink rose promises to soften the skin. Then theres the detoxifying lavender bath salt (with salt sourced from Utah, Bolivia, the Himalayas and the Dead Sea), a collaboration with the Malibu brand OSEA, that hits the water with a satisfying fizz. Finally, after toweling off, try the rose body butter, a collaboration between Follain and Organic Bath Co. People love to luxuriate in the ingredients and take a moment for themselves away from the noise, says Foley, a a huge bath person whos bound to make converts of us all. follain.com  KATE GUADAGNINO

title: Mnuchin Says Estate Tax Repeal Will Help Rich People Most
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump and Republican leaders have positioned a proposed repeal of the estate tax as a way to help farmers, ranchers and small business owners. But on Friday, Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, offered a significant concession about who would benefit the most if the so-called death tax disappears: the rich.

title: The Myth of the Spitting Antiwar Protester
description: So where do these stories come from?

title: Iran, California, Harvey Weinstein: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Emerging Market Bonds Are on a Roll. But How High Is the Risk?
description: It has been nearly two years since the Federal Reserve began to raise its core interest rate, yet income investors in the United States are still waiting for a tailwind to kick in.

title: Caught Sleeping or Worse, Troubled Teachers Will Return to New York Classrooms
description: Francis Blake has not held a permanent position in a New York City public school in at least five years. At his last job, in a Bronx elementary school, records show he was disciplined for incompetence, insubordination and neglect of duties  he had been caught sleeping in a classroom when he was supposed to be helping with dismissal.

title: Donald Trump Takes a Hostage
description: Negotiators warn never to take a hostage you cant shoot. By announcing Friday that the administration would not certify that the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran was in the national interest, Donald Trump has taken a hostage.

title: Canada Letter: The End of a Ritual and a Daring Hostage Rescue
description: For many Canadians, catalog shopping was as much culture as commerce. A mail-order mix-up, for example, is at the heart of Roch Carriers The Hockey Sweater, a classic childrens book that became an equally celebrated animated film.

title: Lawrence Argent, Sculptor Who Was Big on Whimsy, Dies at 60
description: Lawrence Argent, a sculptor known for whimsical, monumental works in public spaces, most notably a 40-foot blue bear that peers with seeming curiosity into a Denver convention center, died on Oct. 4 in Denver. He was 60.

title: Russian Banker Denies Role in Planned Trump Building in Moscow
description: WASHINGTON  A top Russian banker said Friday that his bank never had a role in a project once planned by the Trump Organization to build a tower in Moscow, despite an assertion by one of President Trumps associates that the banker had helped finance the deal.

title: Terry Downes Dies at 81; Middleweight Champion Was Britains Pride
description: Terry Downes, a quick-witted middleweight boxing champion from Britain, nicknamed the Paddington Express, who became wealthy outside the ring by investing in legal betting shops and later did a bit of acting, died on Oct. 6 in Hertfordshire. He was 81.

title: Ex-White House Chief of Staff Is Interviewed by Special Counsel
description: WASHINGTON  Investigators for the special counsels office on Friday interviewed President Trumps former chief of staff, Reince Priebus, according to Mr. Priebuss lawyer.

title: Festival Moves Event After Church Objects to Gay-Themed Content
description: A human rights arts festival scheduled to take place on Sunday in a Lower East Side church hall was scrambling for a new venue after top officials of the New York Archdiocese expressed last-minute concerns that performances dealing with gay and transgender issues were not in line with church teaching.

title: Lawyer for Chelsea Bomb Suspect All but Concedes He Set Blast
description: A defense lawyer for the man accused of blowing up a bomb in Chelsea last year all but conceded on Friday that her client committed the crime, instead focusing her closing arguments to jurors  and claims of innocence  on a second, unexploded device found four blocks away.

title: Trump Alienates Americas Allies and Hands Iran a Victory
description: For months, President Trump has made no secret of his desire to tear up one of the Obama administrations top national security achievements: the nuclear accord with Iran, formally known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, or J.C.P.O.A.

title: In California, Fires So Fast Hesitation Proved Lethal
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif.  With towering flames bearing down, one victim delayed escape in hopes of saving his new truck  but he could not find the keys. An elderly couple slept as danger erupted, not waking until it was too late to flee down their one-lane road. Another couple, who barely missed their chance to drive away, huddled in a pool, surrounded by fire and choking smoke; he survived, but she did not.

title: Not Dead Yet: Obamacare Insurers Are Hanging In There
description: Despite President Trumps best efforts, the Obamacare market hasnt imploded yet.

title: Kenyan Elections in Crisis Again
description: The Kenyan Supreme Courts decision on Sept. 1 to invalidate the countrys presidential election because of widespread irregularities was widely hailed at the time as an important first for African democracy and the rule of law. It may yet prove to be that, if a new poll is seen to be free and fair. That prospect, however, is looking increasingly and dangerously dimmer by the day.

title: Harvey Weinstein May Get Kicked Out of the Oscar Club
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Ninety years ago, Louis B. Mayer created an elite club that would become the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Membership, granted for life, quickly turned into the ultimate indicator of status  moviedoms equivalent of the mobs made man.

title: On Twitter, States That Trump Won Hear Theyre Great! The Rest Hear Mostly Nothing.
description: President Trump said he would be a leader for the entire nation, but so far on Twitter, his preferred method for addressing Americans directly, he has lavished praise exclusively on states he won.

title: Assessing Trumps Criticisms of Iran and the Nuclear Deal
description: President Trump declared his intention not to recertify the Iran nuclear deal in a forceful speech on Friday. But the rationale he provided includes several misleading or incomplete statements about the terms of the deal, what he considers a violation of the agreement and Iran itself. Here is an assessment.

title: A Gem of Californias Shore Becomes a Refuge From Wildfires
description: BODEGA BAY, Calif.  Sue Ann and Wynne Herron come here at least three times each year, to recharge with strolls on the secluded, unspoiled beach, their dog Maxx by their side.

title: What Makes Each Fire Different?
description: A Cal Fire spokeswoman, Lynne Tolmachoff, describes the unique characteristics of six of the fires ravaging Northern California.

title: Still a Workhorse but Now an Astro, Justin Verlander Gets Set for Yankees
description: HOUSTON  Justin Verlander worked 251 innings in 2011. No pitcher has done it since, and it might never happen again. He would like to have challenged himself in an earlier era.

title: Trump Adopts Obama Approach While Seeking to Undo a Legacy
description: WASHINGTON  The president was frustrated. Lawmakers were not passing what he wanted. They were obstructionists, he complained. So he took out his pen, signed his name to an order and took action on his own. Were taking a little different route than we had hoped because getting Congress  they forgot what their pledges were, he said.

title: End to Health Care Subsidies Puts Congress in a Tight Spot
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps decision to cut off critical payments to health insurance companies ratcheted up the pressure on Congress on Friday to take action to protect consumers from soaring premiums, while also adding a combustible new issue to negotiations to avert a government shutdown this year.

title: Quotation of the Day: A Sketchy Story
description: Look at how neatly it was done! You tell me how, late at night with a glass of wine, youre going to do it that neatly.

title: New York State to Release $360 Million Withheld From Citys Hospitals
description: ALBANY  After threats of a lawsuit and accusations of bad faith, the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced late Friday afternoon that it would release some $360 million it had withheld from the citys public hospital system.

title: Stupid Trump Tricks
description: This week Donald Trump failed to stand at attention during a military ceremony. He just sat around talking and telling jokes. My question for today is: Do we need to dwell on this?

title: Fraud Scandals Sap Chinas Dream of Becoming a Science Superpower
description: BEIJING  Having conquered world markets and challenged American political and military leadership, China has set its sights on becoming a global powerhouse in a different field: scientific research. It now has more laboratory scientists than any other country, outspends the entire European Union on research and development, and produces more scientific articles than any other nation except the United States.

title: Woman Who Accused Nelly of Rape Wants to Drop Case
description: A woman who accused the multiplatinum rapper Nelly of raping her on his tour bus after a concert last weekend in Auburn, Wash., has told the local police that she will not testify against him and wishes to end the investigation, her lawyer said Friday.

title: The C.I.A.s Fake News Campaign
description: Russias crafty campaign to hack the 2016 election may seem unprecedented, but in a way its not. Sure, secret agents and front groups have hacked email systems, dumped documents on WikiLeaks, paid an army of internet trolls and spent thousands buying political ads on social media. It all seems new because the technologies are new. But its not the first time a government tried to mess with our heads by manipulating our media.

title: The Real Failure of U.S. Mens Soccer
description: For around 30 years, from the 1986 World Cup through the night of Tuesday, Oct. 10, the United States mens national soccer team managed to project at least a pleasing illusion of progress. Maybe it wasnt always real progress. Maybe it wasnt the kind of spectacular success enjoyed by the United States womens team, which has won three World Cups and four Olympic gold medals and galvanized generations of fans.

title: Some Urgent Questions About Turkey
description: Turkey has been a vital ally of the United States since World War II. It fields NATOs second-largest army, after Americas, and anchors the alliances eastern flank. It hosts military bases that are central to American operations in the Middle East, including Incirlik, where some 50 tactical nuclear weapons are stationed, and serves as a bridge between the Muslim world and the West. After Recep Tayyip Erdogan took office in 2003 and began reforms, Turkey seemed on course to becoming a model Muslim democracy.

title: Spin Out on the Ice
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Yesterday, we compared solving crosswords to breaking into a house, because its the end of the week and my mind tends to drift. Today, we are going to compare solving to tiptoeing delicately through a minefield, also because its the end of the week. But also because its now Saturday, and Sam Ezersky is back.

title: Corrections: October 14, 2017
description: NEW YORK

title: Tesla Fires Hundreds of Workers
description: DETROIT  The electric-car maker Tesla fired hundreds of workers this week after a series of performance reviews conducted during the biggest expansion in the companys history.

title: Downtown Miami: More Than a Gateway to the Beach
description: From a tourism perspective, the city of Miami has long been a gateway to Miami Beach, the sand-fringed barrier island lined in glamorous resorts. But in the past several years, downtown Miami has been undergoing renovation, first as a cultural destination  its acclaimed Perez Art Museum Miami opened in 2013  and more recently as a leisure destination with the recent opening of new hotels such as the SLS Brickell, Langford and East, Miami, restaurants led by the Uruguayan import Quinto La Huella and bars including the rooftop Pawn Broker.

title: Astros Edge Yankees, Who Are Confounded Again by Dallas Keuchel
description: HOUSTON  Dallas Keuchel is a fine pitcher, good enough to win a Cy Young Award two years ago. But when he gets a look at the Yankees pinstripes or their distinctive traveling grays, he morphs into Pedro Martinez or Sandy Koufax  or Cy Young himself.

title: I Was in the Room When Catalonia Made History. Or Didnt? Or Did?
description: A few days after a defiant independence referendum in Catalonia, I met an adviser to Carles Puigdemont, the separatist leader of Spains northeastern region.

title: Resting in Peace in Transylvania
description: From 60 euros (about $71, at .84 euros to the dollar).

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Dirk Gently and Halt and Catch Fire
description: The zany comedy Dirk Gentlys Holistic Detective Agency returns for Season 2. And Halt and Catch Fire ends its run.

title: Northern California Fires Have Destroyed at Least 5,700 Buildings
description: A New York Times analysis found that the Tubbs fire, which hit Santa Rosa, leveled what could be a record number of buildings for the state.

title: 4 Things to Cook While Watching Curb Your Enthusiasm
description: After a six-year hiatus, Curb Your Enthusiasm is back, and not a moment too soon. What better way to honor Larry Davids return to his old shenanigans than with a culinary tour of the most uncomfortable half-hour of television? Below youll find a recipe for Cobb salad, a take on food on a stick and more.

title: Eres un obrero mexicano? Envale un mensaje a los obreros estadounidenses
description: Si trabajas o has trabajado en maquiladoras en Mxico, qu te gustara decirles a los trabajadores de ese sector en Estados Unidos que han perdido sus trabajos?

title: Manufacturing Workers in Mexico: Share a Message With U.S. Workers
description: If you work or have previously worked in manufacturing in Mexico, what would you want to say to such workers in the United States who have lost their jobs?

title: Women Didnt Want It Then and Women Dont Want It Now
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

title: An Alternate Universe of Shopping, in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  It was a scorching day outside, hot even for late summer in Ohio, and yet I was freezing. I had stepped inside the EB Ice Box, a meat-locker-like display at the Eddie Bauer store here that was cooled to 13 degrees Fahrenheit. The metal-sheathed room looked out onto the promenade of an upscale shopping mall, and featured a large block of ice for a bench. Even though I was wearing a down jacket (the room is meant to be a place where customers can test Eddie Bauer wear), the frigid air had gotten under my skin.

title: Why a New York Court Case Has Rattled Turkeys President
description: The conversations caught on wiretaps planted by the Turkish police are alleged to show a conspiracy to help Iran skirt American sanctions by trading gold for gas.

title: When Whistling Is Not Music to Your Ears
description: Q. My fiance and I rent a wonderful apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. A man sits on the stoop across the street and whistles as long as the sun shines. He whistles a repeating pattern, like someone breathing in and out of a harmonica. When we politely ask him to stop, he does, but only until we are out of view. It feels unfair that we cannot enjoy having the windows open in our home. Is there another approach?

title: Surf and Safari: Packages Offer Two Hotels, Two Experiences
description: City or country, jungle or beach, safari or surf? Hotels are taking the decision-making out of travel by offering guests packages that combine different destinations into one vacation.

title: Iowas Swing to Republicans Is a Matter of (Lacking a) Degree
description: CLINTON, Iowa  The Clinton County Democratic Party headquarters is wedged in a nondescript brick building with an unpaved, dusty parking lot. The dated computers, mismatched furniture and portable fan suggest another era. The office is dotted with party mementos, a phone from the 1996 Democratic National Convention in Chicago, and framed photographs of Democratic presidents from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Barack Obama.

title: Becoming a Steelworker Liberated Her. Then Her Job Moved to Mexico.
description: Leer en espaol | Listen to The Daily episode

title: Theres Still Time to Enroll in Obamacare: Five Answers to Questions About Getting Covered
description: Some changes you should know about in the final days to sign up for health insurance.

title: Decipher James Thierres Entangled Dreams at BAM
description: Step onstage with James Thierre and Compagnie du Hanneton as they return to the Brooklyn Academy of Music for the Next Wave Festival with La Grenouille Avait Raison (The Toad Knew).

title: TV News Focuses on Political Side of Weinstein Scandal
description: Allegations of sexual harassment against Harvey Weinstein were the focus of a New York Times investigation last week. But if you were watching television news, the revelations about the Hollywood producer and his victims took a decidedly political turn.

title: Canadian Held Hostage in Afghanistan Says Militants Killed His Child
description: OTTAWA  Joshua Boyle called himself a pilgrim who was engaged in helping in Afghanistan. A man who crossed into Afghanistan with him described him as an adventurer.

title: You Say Cohen. I Say Kohn. Lets (Not) Call the Whole Thing Off!
description: Julie Lees Kohn and Bradley Alexander Cohen were married Oct. 14. Rabbi Jonathan E. Blake officiated at Stonover Farm, an events space in Lenox, Mass.

title: A Courtship Started Under the Midnight Sun
description: Dena Perri Adler and Colin Stone Peacock are to be married Oct. 15 at the Onteora Mountain House in Boiceville, N.Y. Rabbi Marsha Jane Kleinman, the officiant, is to lead the ceremony with Terry Tempest Williams, a conservationist and a friend of the couple.

title: Advice From the Rear-View Mirror
description: Barbara McFadden Allen and Thomas Richard Rocklin were married Oct. 14. The Rev. Jeffery L. Ford, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Old State Capitol in Iowa City.

title: Waiting for Bruce
description: That 68-year-old Broadway ingnue, Bruce Springsteen, was nowhere to be seen at the Hard Rock Cafe in Times Square on Thursday night, having briefly slipped in and out of the after-party being held to celebrate the opening of his show at the Walter Kerr Theater a few hours earlier.

title: Looking for Surprises in Senegal
description: In July, Jake Michaels spent a week in Senegal, documenting contemporary and traditional styles. He was traveling with his girlfriend, Juliette Ballay, and Francine Awa Pipien, who helped them get to know people and places around Dakar, the capital.

title: Camping With John Waters and His Band of Filthy Freaks
description: Hello, muddah. Hello, faddah. Here I am at Camp John Waters.

title: Heard the One About Asias Comedy Scene? First, Youll Need a Permit
description: HONG KONG  Every comedian takes the stage wanting to make people laugh. But it is less satisfying when the audience has been ordered to do so before the first joke has been told.

title: Australia Debates: Does a Warming Planet Really Need More Coal?
description: ABBOT POINT, Australia  In a desolate corner of northeastern Australia, about 100 miles from the nearest town, a grassy stretch of prime grazing land sits above a vein of coal so rich and deep that it could be mined for decades.

title: Why Surge Prices Make Us So Mad: What Springsteen, Home Depot and a Nobel Winner Know
description: When Bruce Springsteen decided to do a run of shows at a Broadway theater with fewer than a thousand seats, he appeared to reject the laws of economics  or at least what would seem to be in his financial best interest.

title: Texas Inmates Donated Nearly $54,000 for Hurricane Relief
description: When Hurricane Katrina slammed into the Gulf Coast 12 years ago, inmates in Texas prisons told their wardens that they wanted to help.

title: Venezuela Votes for Governors in a Deficient Democracy
description: PUERTO CABELLO, Venezuela  For weeks, Alejandro Feo la Cruz, a former opposition mayor who is running for governor, has crisscrossed his state in Venezuela with a simple message: The countrys ruling party can no longer feed its own people.

title: Baba Yaga on the Ganges
description: Allahabad, INDIA  I grew up in Allahabad, a city in northern India on the banks of the Ganges, in the 1980s. Not much happened there, apart from the two seasonal festivals  Holi, which marks the end of winter, and Diwali, the greeter at winters doorstep.

title: Allah Is Found on Viking Funeral Clothes
description: ENKOPING, Sweden  The discovery of Arabic characters that spell Allah and Ali on Viking funeral costumes in boat graves in Sweden has raised questions about the influence of Islam in Scandinavia.

title: Tradition of Helping Neediest Cases Inspires Readers to Give Back
description: They married in a white-walled loft in Manhattan in October 1984. She wore a blue dress. He wore a red tie, freesias blooming from his lapel. After the ceremony, the justice told them to keep their payment and tip.

title: At North Carolina, a Sigh of Relief and a New Championship Banner
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  The annual basketball tip-off event at the University of North Carolina has been called Late Night With Roy for the past 15 years, ever since Roy Williams, a prodigal son of Asheville, returned from the University of Kansas to take over the Tar Heels.

title: Ready or Not (and Theyre Not), the Weary Cubs Take On the Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES  After the madness of a four-and-a-half-hour, do-or-die Game 5 was over and the Chicago Cubs had survived to move on to the next round of the postseason, Jon Lester stood in a raucous visitors clubhouse at Nationals Park in Washington.

title: Wary of Hackers, States Move to Upgrade Voting Systems
description: WASHINGTON  State election officials, worried about the integrity of their voting systems, are pressing to make them more secure ahead of next years midterm elections.

title: Doubts Grow Over Archbishops Account of When He Knew of Abuse
description: LONDON  The Anglican Church has been embroiled for most of this year in a scandal involving decades-old abuses that occurred in elite Christian holiday camps for boys where Justin Welby worked in his 20s, before eventually assuming his current post as the Most Rev. Archbishop of Canterbury.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Fear, or the lack of it, is such a great subject for a column about puzzle solving. Fear can hold people back in many facets of their lives, but its especially true when it comes to learning to solve puzzles. For some reason, many people have surprisingly little faith in their abilities, and I wish I could convince them that they know so much more than they think they do and can do so much more than they believe they can.

title: Back Home, a Unanimous Verdict on Corker vs. Trump: Thats Just Bob
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  Liddle Bob Corker is kind of a big deal around here.

title: Black Lawmakers Hold a Particular Grievance With Facebook: Racial Exploitation
description: WASHINGTON  For more than an hour, Sheryl Sandberg, Facebooks high-profile chief operating officer, sheepishly pledged to do better  over and over  as stern-faced members of the Congressional Black Caucus grilled her on Thursday about Russian ads aimed at exploiting racial divisions during last years election.

title: Promise the Moon? Easy for Trump. But Now Comes the Reckoning.
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump leaves little doubt about what he thinks of his predecessors top domestic and international legacies. The health care program enacted by President Barack Obama is outrageous and absolutely destroying everything in its wake. The nuclear deal with Iran is one of the worst and most one-sided transactions the United States has ever entered into.

title: La Guardia Airport Terminal Partially Evacuated After Bomb Threat
description: A disgruntled customer prompted a partial shutdown of a terminal at La Guardia Airport on Saturday morning after telling an airline employee he had a bomb, the police said.

title: The Ashes in Napa
description: The first time my familys hillside house in Napa, Calif., burned to the ground, it was 1960 and my father was 14 years old. Everyone escaped in a pickup truck, bringing little more than a handful of pictures and the clothes on their backs. Being novices, we took all the wrong things, my uncle remembers. We grabbed lamps and blenders instead of photographs. The next day, mostly everything was gone. The hill was charred earth and black trees.

title: Sarah Polley: The Men You Meet Making Movies
description: One day, when I was 19 years old, I was in the middle of a photo shoot for a Miramax film when I was suddenly told it was time to leave. I was wearing a little black dress, showing a lot of cleavage, lying seductively on my side and looking slyly at the camera. The part I had played in the movie, Guinevere, could not have been more removed from this pose. My character was an awkward girl, bumbling, in fact, who wore sweatshirts and jeans, and had little sense of her sexual power. But this was how they were going to sell the movie, and at a certain point, I was tired of being a problem, which is how a female actor is invariably treated whenever she points out that she is being objectified or not respected.

title: Why I Went to North Korea
description: Since my five-day visit to North Korea recently, Ive encountered pushback from critics who ask, Why go?

title: Harvey Weinstein, Hollywoods Oldest Horror Story
description: In her autobiography, Child Star, Shirley Temple described going with her mother to see her new bosses at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer after leaving Fox.

title: The Rohingya Who Made It to Chicago
Aaron Hernandezs Family Drops C.T.E. Suit Against N.F.L., for Now
description: The family of Aaron Hernandez, the former New England Patriots tight end who committed suicide in jail in April, has dropped its lawsuit against the National Football League, but left open the possibility of refiling it in a different court.

title: Elephant Tramples Rohingya Refugees in Bangladesh, Killing Four
description: Four Rohingya refugees were trampled to death by an elephant in a makeshift camp in the Coxs Bazar area of Bangladesh on Saturday morning.

title: Why Are Millennials Wary of Freedom?
description: Young Americans seem to be losing faith in freedom. Why?

title: 4 Ways Trump Has Moved to Undo His Predecessors Legacies

title: Key Maduro Ally in Venezuela Is Linked to Illegal Campaign Gifts
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Odebrecht, the Brazilian construction giant that ran a vast bribery scheme in the Americas, made campaign contributions to numerous Venezuelan candidates, including Diosdado Cabello, one of the countrys most powerful politicians, according to a video released on Saturday by Venezuelas ousted attorney general.

title: The 70s and Us
description: I came of age in the 60s and 70s, when all the rules about behavior and workplaces were different, Harvey Weinstein wrote in his awful pseudo-apology, just before the fake Jay-Z quote and the promise to go to war with the N.R.A. That was the culture then.

title: The Fire Is Roaring Over the Ridge. Its Time to Go.
description: SANTA ROSA,  Calif.  Blaring car horns warned of the rushing wildfires in Northern California last week. So did exploding propane tanks and police megaphones. The smell of smoke was a sign of what loomed on the horizon. Frantic banging on the door by neighbors was an indication that the fire was dangerously close.

title: The Survivors Guilt of a New American Citizen
description: I spent my early childhood in a mountainous region in the southern Dominican Republic, living in a house made of wooden planks with a tin roof. My parents had emigrated to New York, so my grandmother was charged with taking care of me.

title: Documenting U.S. Role in Democracys Fall and Dictators Rise in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  An old rotary phone rings insistently.

title: Trump Tweets Approval After Health Care Stocks Plunged
description: It is unlike President Trump to cheer when stocks fall, but early on Saturday he did just that.

title: Harvey Weinstein Ousted From Motion Picture Academy
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods de facto governing body, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, voted overwhelmingly on Saturday to immediately expel Harvey Weinstein, breaking with 90 years of precedent and turning one of the biggest Oscar players in history into a hall-of-fame pariah.

title: Born in Auschwitz, Israeli Artist, 102, Harnesses the Dark and the Light
description: JERUSALEM  She painted gray and black flowers, their innate beauty discernible only through hints of light.

title: In Costa Rica, Loss in the Clouds
description: MONTEVERDE, Costa Rica  At the end of April, my mom to old age. At the end of May, my brother Rick to cancer. In mid-June, our next-door neighbor to a heart attack. So grief comes sometimes as the clouds do here, almost every day. Gray wisps descend and curl around the trees and before long I am engulfed in fog.

title: Lies, Lies, Lies, Lies, Lies, Lies, Lies, Lies, Lies, Lies
description: Modern conservatives have been lying about taxes pretty much from the beginning of their movement. Made-up sob stories about family farms broken up to pay inheritance taxes, magical claims about self-financing tax cuts, and so on go all the way back to the 1970s. But the selling of tax cuts under Trump has taken things to a whole new level, both in terms of the brazenness of the lies and their sheer number. Both the depth and the breadth of the dishonesty make it hard even for those of us who do this for a living to keep track.

title: America Loves Plausible Deniability
description: In the end, which is where we live now, it turns out that America was brought low not by war or economic collapse or environmental catastrophe (though none of those are off the table) but by plausible deniability.

title: Would You Buy a Self-Driving Future From These Guys?
description: When the owner of an automated Tesla was killed in a crash last year, the carmakers founder, Elon Musk, urged journalists to peer into the future.

title: The Rich, the Powerful and the Manhattan D.A.
description: Cyrus Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, was asked a few days ago if he deemed it appropriate for a prosecutor to take campaign money, as he does, from lawyers who have dealings with his office. Mr. Vance said, The answer is that its legal.

title: Jose Altuves Mad Dash Gives the Astros Another Win Over the Yankees
description: HOUSTON  At the crack of the bat, Jose Altuve bounded away from first, tracking Carlos Correas one-out liner into the right-center-field gap in the bottom of the ninth inning. After a few steps, Altuves legs were churning and as he sharply rounded second base, he picked up the sign from the third-base coach Gary Pettis, who was furiously waving  his arm like a ramped-up windmill  Altuve toward home.

Lombardy, who was one of the most talented and promising chess players of his generation, winning titles and accolades while he was still a teenager, but who all but gave up the game at the height of his career to become a priest, died on Friday in Martinez, Calif. He was 79.

title: Corrections: October 15, 2017
description: BOOK REVIEW

title: 21 Years Later, Jeff Maier Gets to Relive His Big Moment
description: HOUSTON  His favorite team was locked in a scoreless playoff game late on Saturday afternoon. But Jeff Maier, 33, is a parent first and a Yankees fan second, and understands an important rule of fatherhood: When your 6-year-old son asks to play catch on a crisp autumn day, you do it.

title: Dodgers Begin Their Revenge Against the Cubs as Yasiel Puig Steps Up
description: LOS ANGELES  En route to their first World Series title in 108 years last fall, the Chicago Cubs had to get past the Los Angeles Dodgers in the National League Championship Series. The deciding contest, Game 6, was at Wrigley Field and when the Cubs won, beating Clayton Kershaw in the process, and their players and fans celebrated deliriously, the Dodgers stewed in the cramped visitors clubhouse, unable to leave because of the raucous scene outside the ballpark.

They picked through burned-out cars and hunted as best they could in a collapsed hotel.

title: Faded Yukon Gold Rush Town, Population 20, Mines Its Weirdness
description: KENO CITY, Yukon Territory  The journey to the heart of Yukons historic mineral wealth started with a question posed to a waitress at the aptly titled Gold Rush hotel in Whitehorse, the territorial capital: Whats the weirdest place in Yukon?

description: Race relations in the United States have been a central component in many of this years major news stories. White nationalists rallied in Charlottesville, Va., after the City Council voted to remove a statue of Robert E. Lee. Black athletes have protested police brutality and racial injustice by kneeling during the national anthem.

title: Feds Janet Yellen Says the Economy Remains in Good Health
description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said on Sunday that the American economy was in good health in an upbeat assessment that reinforced expectations the Fed is planning to raise its benchmark interest rate later this year.

description: It starts with a whisper. A prominent man has used his wealth and power to harass or abuse a woman  or worse  and then to intimidate her, or to buy her silence.

title: National Anthem Controversies, From Helsinki to Kuwait
description: National anthems are ticklish things, as anyone who has paid attention to the news of the past few weeks knows. What started last year as a gesture by one football player has mushroomed into a national debate about patriotism; about protest; about the patriotism of protest.

title: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: A Shakespeare Scholar Turned Nazi Hunter
description: Not all superheroes wear capes, and Elizebeth Smith Friedman should be the subject of a future Wonder Woman movie. In The Woman Who Smashed Codes, Jason Fagone recounts the stranger-than-fiction story of how the 23-year-old Smith was hired in 1916, along with other scholars, by an eccentric tycoon who wanted to find secret messages in the work of Shakespeare. Those messages didnt exist, but within a year Smith was recruited into a wartime code-breaking project. (American history is very strange, Fagone told me.) Smith met and married the cryptologist William Friedman; helped break up smuggling rings during Prohibition; and spent World War II successfully decoding messages sent between Nazi spies, ruining the Germans operations in South America, among other triumphs. Below, Fagone talks about the long odds he faced in filling in the gaps in his subjects life, the role sexism played in her career and more.

title: Helping Fellow Victims of Hurricane Harvey
description: Dorothy Edmundson turned to a food bank for assistance after the storm destroyed her home in Houston. Then she became a volunteer.

title: Storm Victim Finds Help, and Purpose, at a Houston Food Bank
description: HOUSTON  Dorothy Edmundson has always been the responsible one: the middle child who took care of her brother and sister, the dental office employee who rose from hygienist to manager, the watchful mother who whisked away the school cafeteria plate of corn served to her highly allergic daughter.

title: Taliban Deny Fighters Raped American Hostage and Killed Baby

title: Subsidies, Spite, and Supply Chains
description: As many people have been pointing out, Trumps decision to cancel cost-sharing subsidies for health plans is a rare policy trifecta: it raises prices, reduces the number of people with insurance, and costs taxpayers money. Nor is there evidence of any political strategy worthy of the name. This is policy driven by sheer spite: Trump cant get what he wants from Congress, so hes going to punish innocent people.

title: Five Arrested in Georgia in Heinous 1983 Killing of Black Man
description: The authorities in Georgia have reopened a cold case and arrested five people  including two law enforcement officials  in connection with what the local sheriff said was a brutal, racially motivated murder of a black man 34 years ago.

title: Jimmy Kimmel on Health Care, National Tragedies and Twitter Feuds
description: In the up-and-down landscape of late-night television, Jimmy Kimmel has lately found himself at the top of a crowded field. In his 15th season at ABCs Jimmy Kimmel Live!, he has gained new visibility as a result of monologues in which he has addressed sweeping news events in intimately personal terms. In May, a few days after his newborn son, Billy, underwent emergency open-heart surgery, Mr. Kimmel was on the air urging against any health care reform that would deny coverage to people with pre-existing medical conditions.

title: Truck Explosions Kill Hundreds in Somalia

title: After the Las Vegas Shooting, Concertgoers Became Medics

Volunteers combed the grounds for survivors and carried out the injured. Strangers used belts as makeshift tourniquets to stanch bleeding, and then others sped the wounded to hospitals in the back seats of cars and the beds of pickup trucks.

This was an August morning in 2012, and few fans would show up to Minute Maid Park later that night. The Astros would be shut out and lose for the 25th time in 28 games.

And the day promised to be a very long one: The government had relocated her voting site from the place she had cast ballots since 1972 to a distant, crime-ridden neighborhood.

Nathalie and Michael Internicola had about 15 minutes to grab what they could as the flames roared toward their house, and it wasnt much: Some clothes, passports, their phones. They are grateful to be alive, they said, but as for what comes next and how and where they might rebuild their lives, they dont have a clue.

They won a big victory last month when Congress set aside its efforts to pass a destructive bill. But now the coalition has a new fight.

title: Trump, Chieftain of Spite
description: It must be cold and miserable standing in the shadow of someone greater and smarter, more loved and more admired. It must be infuriating to have risen on the wings of your derision of that persons every decision, and even his very existence, and yet not be able to measure up  in either stratagem or efficacy  when you sit where that person once sat.

title: Star Trek: Discovery Season 1, Episode 5: Sarus Moment
description: One of the best episodes of Star Trek: The Next Generation was the two-part The Best of Both Worlds, in which the Borg kidnap Picard and turn him into Locutus. Through a different lens, though, this was a story about Riker (Jonathan Frakes), who is forced to take command of the Enterprise and is unsure whether he is ready to do so. On its surface, the story was about the lengths a crew will go to save Picard and the potential destruction of the Federation. But it was also, if not more so, about seeing Riker develop beyond just a competent first officer. (Part of this was due to Patrick Stewarts contract negotiations.)

title: The Deuce Season 1, Episode 6: Housecleaning
description: On the third season of David Simons The Wire, a rogue Baltimore police major named Bunny Colvin experiments with a project called Hamsterdam, a three-zone area where drug dealers and users can congregate and do their business without getting harassed by the cops. Nearing the end of his career, Colvin puts legalization in the petri dish, theorizing that Hamsterdam will lessen crimes in afflicted neighborhoods and allow social services to distribute condoms and clean needles in a concentrated space. Although the show is careful to show the deplorable state of these fetid, smoke-filled rowhouses, the stats wind up supporting his thesis. As a reward, hes hustled to early retirement and the streets return to the status quo.

title: One Person Believed to Be Missing After Oil Rig Explodes in Louisiana

title: Martin Amis on Lenins Deadly Revolution
description: It was not a good idea that somehow went wrong or withered away. It was a very bad idea from the outset, and one forced into life  or the life of the undead  with barely imaginable self-righteousness, pedantry, dynamism, and horror. The chief demerit of the Marxist program was its point-by-point defiance of human nature. Bolshevik leaders subliminally grasped the contradiction almost at once; and their rankly Procrustean answer was to leave the program untouched and change human nature. In practical terms this is what totalitarianism really means: On their citizens such regimes make a total claim.

Its the latest version of Californias new normal: Add masks to your emergency kit, dont breathe deeply and try to stay inside.

description: MEMPHIS  Its easy to understand why some people in this town of soul music and dry-rub ribs dont know what to make of the tall tech billionaire in a big white cowboy hat who has been opening restaurants and buying up hundreds of acres of land that used to grow cotton.

title: Raising Concerns About a Widely Used Test to Measure Fertility
description: Michele K. Bourquin, an account executive from Atlanta, was 36 and divorced when she first looked into freezing her eggs.

title: New Home for Gems and Minerals at the Museum of Natural History
description: Outcroppings of rocks hundreds of millions of years old occur naturally in Central Park, but even more exotic gems and minerals will be vividly on display across the street when the American Museum of Natural Historys new Allison and Roberto Mignone Halls of Gems and Minerals open in 2019 in conjunction with the museums 150th anniversary.

title: Roy Dotrice, Nimble British Actor Familiar on Both Sides of Atlantic, Dies at 94
description: Roy Dotrice, a British stage, film and television actor who began performing as a prisoner of war in Germany and worked in Britain and America for six decades, notably in one-man shows portraying Abe Lincoln, the diarist John Aubrey and other historical figures, died on Monday at his home in London. He was 94.
