title: When the Doctors Mother Has Cancer
description: I want you to talk to me like Im one of your patients, not like Im your mother.

title: Kahlil Josephs New Film Is Steeped in Harlems History. And His Own.
description: It was Kahlil Josephs brother who made him an artist. Or at least thats one way to describe how Mr. Joseph, a successful director who has worked with Kendrick Lamar and Beyonc, came to premiere his film Fly Paper at the New Museum this fall.

title: What 8 Golfers and Fans Wore to the Presidents Cup
description: This years Presidents Cup, which pits male golfers from the United States against some of the worlds best players, took place Sept. 28 at Liberty National Golf Club in Jersey City, N.J.  With spectators gathered, top American players including Rickie Fowler and Phil Mickelson managed to retain their trophy against opponents including Indias Anirban Lahiri. Yes, it was a sea of polo shirts and khakis, but not all polo shirts are equal. Heres a sampling of what golfers and their fans wore.

title: A Readers Guide to Impeachment
description: This week, Harvard University Press released Cass R. Sunsteins latest book, Impeachment: A Citizens Guide. The timing is fortuitous. Although the charges filed by Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, did not implicate the president, the subject of impeachment is on peoples minds. We asked Mr. Sunstein, a professor at Harvard Law School, to recommend books that might help readers understand the history and process of charging a public official with misconduct.

title: Trumps Trade Endgame Could Be the Undoing of Global Rules
description: What if President Trumps ultimate goal is to kill the World Trade Organization?

title: Caroline Shaws and the swallow
description: Recorded during a Trinity Choir rehearsal

title: Michael van der Aas Shelter
description: Recorded by the Nederlands Kamerkoor in Utrecht.

title: Pasta Flyer, Mark Ladners Latest, Opens in Greenwich Village
description: PASTA FLYER When you promise miracles like a good plate of pasta in mere minutes, you have to get it right. That effort is what has taken the chef, Mark Ladner, many more months than he anticipated to engineer his concept. Now, with skills honed in the serious precincts of Del Posto, after time in some of the earthier Batali-Bastianich properties like Otto, hes ready. Enter the restaurant up some stairs, and you go straight to the counter where the action is. Its a completely new design, and its much better, he said. Last spring, poised to open, he and his business partner, Nastassia Lopez, decided their kitchen plan wasnt working, so they had the whole thing rebuilt to make the pasta assembly line more efficient, always with an eye on the stopwatch. Mr. Ladners combination of speed and quality at a low price involves a freezing method. He offers three types of pastas with a basic marinara sauce for $6 to $7; adding pesto or meat costs another dollar, and 50 cents gets you a topping like cheese. Beverages include wine. To one side in the high-ceilinged space are plush banquettes, tables and chairs: 510 Avenue of the Americas (13th Street), no phone, pastaflyer.com.

title: Review: Frank Serpico Updates the Story of the Man Behind a Classic Movie
description: This movies intention is in its title. The documentary Frank Serpico fills out an American classic that is now almost 45 years old. Serpico, the 1973 movie directed by Sidney Lumet and starring Al Pacino, was an adaptation of a book by Peter Maas about a New York City police officer who fought corruption in the ranks and got, among other things, a bullet in the head for his trouble. The real-life subject is now 81 years old, whippet-thin, and a storyteller and self-examiner of no small gifts.

title: Isidora Zebeljans Salmo 78
description: Recording by the Nederlands Kamerkoor in Utrecht.

title: Hilde Lysiak, Reporter, Author, 10-Year-Old
description: The first book in the Hilde Cracks the Case series opens with 9-year-old Hilde Lysiak outside her local police station in the town of Selinsgrove, Pa., following up on a tip about a break-in on Orange Street. The on-duty officer refuses to divulge any information, but if shes going to break the story in her newspaper, The Orange Street News, she has to investigate using six basic reporting questions: Who? What? Where? When? Why? How?

title: A TriBeCa Store With Built-In P.R. Buzz
description: Its no surprise that fashion boutiques hire publicists, but how many publicists open their own boutique? Thats the back story to 180 the Store in TriBeCa, which was opened by Denise Williamson in the same building, 180 Duane Street, where she runs her fashion P.R. agency, Williamson PR. The idea is to showcase her clients (mostly Japanese labels including Visvim and Nanamica), as well as other brands that she adores. The 2,500-square-foot space is constantly in flux, and is used regularly for events and pop-up installations.

title: Mohammed Fairouzs Diversions
description: Recorded by the Nederlands Kamerkoor in Utrecht.

title: Pitch in All 7 World Series Games? Brandon Morrow Just Might Do It
description: LOS ANGELES  The record has persisted through the decades, even as relief pitchers take more and more innings from starters. Only one man has ever pitched in all seven games of a World Series.

title: David Langs if i sing
description: Recorded by the Nederlands Kamerkoor in Utrecht.

title: Review: Greta Gerwigs Lady Bird Is Big-Screen Perfection
description: Christine McPherson, who prefers to be called Lady Bird  its her given name, she insists, in the sense that its given to me, by me  is a senior at a Catholic girls high school. Sister Sarah Joan (Lois Smith), the principal, has read Lady Birds college application essay. Its clear how much you love Sacramento, Sister Sarah remarks. This comes as a surprise, both to Lady Bird and the viewer, who is by now aware of Lady Birds frustration with her hometown.

title: At 90, Still Raising the Bar for Himself  and the Other Guys
description: Alex Katz lives and works on the top floor of a prime SoHo building, in a corner loft with the light and square footage most artists in New York only dream of.

title: To Protect U.S. Solar Manufacturing, Trade Body Recommends Limits on Imports
description: Trade officials recommended on Tuesday that the United States impose restrictions on solar power equipment purchased from abroad, including tariffs of up to 35 percent, setting the stage for one of President Trumps first major trade decisions.

title: Review: In 1945, Hungarian Villagers Are Forced to Revisit Wartime Sins
description: The men in hats arrive by train and slowly walk the dusty road toward the village, following the horse-drawn flatbed that carries their cargo. The stationmaster bicycles ahead of them to issue a warning at the watering hole; the residents begin to whisper. Its the wedding day of the son of the town clerk, who doesnt want any trouble with elections coming up. The wedding itself seems like a shaky affair, with an uneasy groom and a bride whose previous fianc is still hovering.

title: Nico Muhlys Marrow
description: Recorded by the Nederlands Kamerkoor in Utrecht.

title: Portray Mexico in a Balanced Way, a State Official Says
description: To the Editor:

title: Did the World Get Aung San Suu Kyi Wrong?
description: WASHINGTON  This is not the happy ending we were led to expect.

title: Teaching Bats to Say Move Out of My Way in Many Dialects
description: I was raised by grandparents who spoke only Mandarin, so I did not speak English until I went to preschool in Philadelphia. There, guided by English-speaking teachers and surrounded by toddlers babbling in loose English, I adopted the new language quickly.

title: Zad Moultakas Sakata
description: Recorded by the Nederlands Kamerkoor in Utrecht.

title: Mr Porters New Private Label (and Getting Cozy Indoors)
description: Charlie Hedin grew up sailing around Marstrand, a small seaside town in Sweden. So when he developed his textile brand, Tekla, he drew inspiration from the Scandinavian vista: sky blue, ash black, sun-bleached yellow and soft gray.

title: Evelin Seppars Psalm 129
description: Recorded by the Nederlands Kamerkoor in Utrecht.

title: In a Superstar Economy, a Bull Market in Superstar Harassers
description: In the recent wave of reports of workplace sexual harassment, a recurring theme stands out: the willingness of companies supposed overseers to ignore credible allegations in order to retain a perceived star.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: $5.72 MILLION

title: Letting the Rich Keep Their Tax Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock, Reminiscence and Sci-Fi Will Be Part of Under the Radar Festival
description: The Public Theaters 2018 Under the Radar Festival will feature pieces inspired by the work of the pioneering science fiction writer Octavia Butler and the influential rock critic Lester Bangs, as well as an autobiographical show from the New Yorker writer Adam Gopnik.

title: Review: The Light of the Moon and the Trauma of Rape
description: When we meet Bonnie, a young architect in Brooklyn, shes on her way to a well-deserved night out. Bonnie drinks and dances, swatting away a few overeager hands. After turning down her friends offer to split a cab, she stumbles toward home. Bonnie puts on her headphones, shes in her own world. And then Bonnie is pulled into an alleyway, where she is brutally raped by a stranger.

title: Another Venue for Sexual Harassment Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Manafort Is the Tip of the Iceberg
description: As a tax professor who specializes in anti-money laundering, what is most striking to me about the criminal indictment against Paul Manafort and Rick Gates is how easy they made it look to launder nearly $20 million dollars from prying government eyes over a period of nearly 10 years.

title: Netflix Suspends Production of House of Cards
description: Production on the final season of House of Cards was suspended Tuesday, two days after its star, Kevin Spacey, was accused of having made an unwanted sexual advance toward a 14-year-old boy in the 1980s.

title: June Robles Birt, Whose Abduction at 6 Gripped the Nation, Is Dead at 87
description: By 1934, Tucson figured its Wild West days were behind it. The legendary gunfight at the O.K. Corral, down the road in Tombstone, had occurred fully a half-century before, and Tucson was blooming as a desert mecca for tourists and respiratory patients.

title: Trump Can Pardon Manafort. He Shouldnt.
description: The indictments on Monday of the former Trump campaign officials Paul Manafort and Rick Gates have some prominent conservatives openly considering desperate measures. The Wall Street Journal editorial board called on the special counsel whose investigation led to the indictments, Robert Mueller, to resign, arguing that he lacks the critical distance to carry out the inquiry. So did the New York Post columnist Michael Goodwin.

title: The Feminine Mystique
description: A forgotten generation of women artists create work about sex thats more vital than ever.

title: The Feminist Pioneers Making Provocative Art About Sex
description: THIS SUMMER IN LOS ANGELES, a hairy, phallic-looking screw painted by Judith Bernstein extended across 180 feet of the exterior of Venus gallery in Boyle Heights. This month at MoMA PS1 in Queens, men and women stripped down to their underwear and rubbed each other with raw fish in a video by Carolee Schneemann. And in London, pink double-headed phalluses bloomed from cacti in Renate Bertlmanns sculptures at the Frieze art fair.

title: Lucky Timing for Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke
description: To the Editor:

title: Review: The B-Side Is an Extraordinary Masterclass in Listening
description: The Wooster Groups The B-Side: Negro Folklore From Texas State Prisons, first seen at the Performing Garage in Manhattan, is now at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn, where it opened on Friday. A record album interpretation, directed by Kate Valk, the production has returned with its original cast of Eric Berryman (who conceived the show), Jasper McGruder and Philip Moore. It runs through March 24. Here is our review from 2017.

title: Vivian Maier, Through a Clearer Lens
description: No one would find the prospect of posthumous fame more appalling than the photographer Vivian Maier. In life, she fanatically concealed her traces: She liked strong bolts on her doors, fake names (she had at least three in rotation) and what seemed to be a spurious French accent. She rarely discussed or shared her work. Many assumed she was homeless.

title: Facebook, Paul Manafort, Manus Island: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Your Grandmas Favorite Bargain Store Wants You
description: At Next Century, the boutique-minded new shop inside Century 21, Isaac Gindi, a second-generation garmento, and his new hire, Chrissie Miller (native New Yorkers both), were putting the finishing touches on a whole new vision for a metropolitan institution.

title: Net Neutrality: Why Artists and Activists Cant Afford to Lose It
description: Somewhere at a comedy club, a new comedian is about to hit the stage for the first time. She will bring with her the modern tool of the trade: her cellphone, equipped with the notes she has typed, a recording app, and five minutes of material that isnt worth all that technology. This set is going to bomb. Hard. But she will repeat this process  night in, night out, until over time, that five-minute performance becomes tighter and more polished. Eventually, shell ask a friend to use a phone to record a set. And that night she will kill. Utterly destroy the room. That will be the first time she uploads footage of herself performing to the internet. Her life will never be the same.

title: Hear 9 New Psalm Settings for Challenging Times
description: When Lincoln Center first planned the Psalms Experience, an ambitious series of concerts that includes musical settings of all 150 biblical psalms, it was thought of as an antidote to what felt like a terrible year: 2016.

title: Republicans Delay Releasing Tax Bill, Signaling Trouble for Party
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans delayed the rollout of their tax bill late on Tuesday, in a sign of early trouble for what party leaders had hoped would be a quick victory.

title: After 25 Years, Michael Tilson Thomas Will Leave San Francisco Symphony
description: Michael Tilson Thomas, whose trailblazing leadership of the San Francisco Symphony spurred American classical musics westward expansion, announced on Tuesday that he would step down as its music director in 2020, after his 25th season.

title: Terror Attack Kills 8 and Injures 11 in Manhattan
description: Read the latest on the Manhattan truck attack with our reporting on Wednesdays developments.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Australia in November
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess TV and movie recommendation site. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter, here.

title: Aetna Could Offer CVS Valuable Protection
description: Aetnas third-quarter results show its value to CVS Health. Revenue at the $56 billion health-coverage firm fell 5 percent in the three months to the end of September, partly because it pulled out of health insurance exchanges. But profit jumped 48 percent as the company kept costs under control. That offers alluring protection for CVS, whose pharmacy and drug-benefit business is threatened by rising competition and transparency.

title: Josh Hutcherson of The Hunger Games Keeps His Wardrobe Basic
description: Josh Hutcherson, who has been acting since he was 9, is quite the veteran of sci-fi. At 25, he is perhaps best known for playing Peeta Mellark from The Hunger Games, and this month he will starring as a time-traveling janitor in Hulus Future Man. Off camera, Mr. Hutcherson prefers a more earthbound existence, hanging out in his Los Angeles home in T-shirts, jeans, caps and Adidas Sambas.

title: Hes George Papadopoulos, Just Not That George Papadopoulos
description: George Papadopoulos is having a rough couple of days.

title: The Messages of the Mueller Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Papadopoulos? Decoding Muellers First Legal Moves
description: The New York Times journalists Mark Mazzetti, Matt Apuzzo and Adam Goldman analyze the indictments of Paul Manafort and Richard Gates, and the cooperation of George Papadopoulos with the investigation of Robert S. Mueller III.

title: Your Favorite Books on Vietnam
description: Last week we asked readers for their favorite books on Vietnam and the Vietnam War. Dozens responded, with suggestions ranging from the well known to the obscure. Below are some of them; to chime in further, click here.

title: For Philip Murphy, Key Rsum Entries Are Often Left Unspoken
description: The rsum for Philip D. Murphy, the Democratic candidate for governor of New Jersey, features two impressive entries: a 23-year tenure at Goldman Sachs, with high-ranking positions in Frankfurt and Hong Kong, and a four-year tenure under President Barack Obama as ambassador to Germany.

title: Running Ones Own Path
description: Radio host Peter Sagal and game designer Mike Selinker talk puzzles.

title: Lets Hear It for Those With Low Libidos
description: The Dear Sugars podcast is an advice program hosted by Steve Almond and Cheryl Strayed. The audio contains more letters; submissions are welcome at dearsugars@nytimes.com. If youre reading this on desktop, click the play button below to listen. Mobile readers can find Dear Sugars on the Podcasts app (iPhone and iPad) or Radio Public (Android and tablet).

title: Bette Midler, Michael Kors and Eric Schmidt at Hulaween Benefit
description: The annual gala for the New York Restoration Project took place at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine

title: Connecticut Adopts a Budget After Months of Debate and Delays
description: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut approved a two-year, $40.2 billion budget on Tuesday that includes spending cuts and a variety of measures meant to improve a dire financial situation and end a stalemate that forced the state to operate without a budget for 123 days.

title: Exxon Will Pay $2.5 Million for Pollution at Gulf Coast Plants
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Justice announced Tuesday that Exxon Mobil will pay $2.5 million in fines for flaring gases at eight plants along the Gulf Coast. Agency officials said the announcement was evidence of the Trump administrations commitment to enforcing the nations environmental laws.

title: Retired Priest, 96, Arraigned on Child Pornography Charges
description: A 96-year-old retired priest who was once a high-ranking official of the Archdiocese of New York was arraigned in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on Tuesday on charges of possessing child pornography. The pictures, which were on his computer, were of girls ages 8 to 14 years old performing sex acts with men or posing naked, the Bronx district attorney said.

title: A Refusal to Compromise? Civil War Historians Beg to Differ
description: Two months after President Trump stirred fierce debate with a defense of Confederate monuments, his chief of staff, John F. Kelly, has waded back into the fray of Civil War history.

title: College Application Website Went Down as Deadline Looms
description: For thousands of students anxiously trying to apply to colleges, it must have felt like disaster: Just before midnight on Monday, with barely 48 hours to go before the early deadline at many colleges, the web portal used by more than a million students a year started balking, and then shut down completely.

title: Red Carpet Looks by Burberry
description: Christopher Baileys Burberry designs are a favorite on the red carpet.

title: Columbia Professor Accused of Sexual Harassment Steps Down
description: A distinguished historian at Columbia University accused this month of kissing and groping a 29-year-old female doctoral student stepped down from teaching and other student-related duties, the university told students and faculty members in an email on Monday.

title: Mark Halperins Game Change Partner Says He Was Unaware
description: For the political journalists Mark Halperin and John Heilemann, work on the third installment of their popular Game Change book series  set to be an insiders account of the final two months of the 2016 presidential race  came to an abrupt halt last Wednesday at around 10 a.m.

title: James Martin, Who Spurred G.O.P. Gains in the South, Dies at 99
description: James D. Martin, a states-rights Republican whose squeaker loss in a 1962 race for the United States Senate from Alabama and election to the House two years later helped crack the Democratic Solid South, died on Monday at his home in Gadsden, Ala. He was 99.

title: De Blasio Donor Says Access to City Hall Didnt Always Lead to Results
description: A real estate broker and donor to Mayor Bill de Blasio who claimed to have bought favors from city officials conceded during cross-examination on Tuesday that three examples he had initially cited as evidence of his direct line to the mayor had not always resulted in the response he was looking for.

title: World Series 2017: How the Dodgers Won Game 6, Inning by Inning
description: Follow our live coverage of World Series Game 7 here.

title: Please Take All Your Belongings
description: Dear Diary:

title: Trump Plans for Nuclear Arsenal Require $1.2 Trillion, Congressional Review States
description: The price tag of President Trumps vision of remaking the American nuclear arsenal soared on Tuesday as a new government estimate put the cost of a 30-year makeover at $1.2 trillion, more than 20 percent higher than earlier figures.

title: Lower Manhattan, White House, Paul Manafort: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Terror Attack in Lower Manhattan: Im Scared. Im Scared.
description: Amateur video appears to show a suspect trying to flee the scene of a deadly vehicle attack near the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan before being stopped by the police.

title: From the Archives: The Kidnapping of Little June
description: June Robles is kidnapped on April 25, 1934, and buried in a metal cage in the Arizona desert. A note is then delivered to her family demanding a ransom of $15,000.

title: Devils Youth Movement Is Off to a Promising Start
description: NEWARK  During the Devils game against the Ottawa Senators on Friday, Frank Piserchia wore a red Devils jersey with the number 30 stitched across the front and back. It was a homage to the former goalie Martin Brodeur, the cornerstone on the 1995, 2000 and 2003 Stanley Cup championship teams.

title: What We Know and Dont Know About the Manhattan Terror Attack
description: Eight people were killed on Tuesday, and 12 injured when a rented pickup truck plowed down a bike lane that runs along the West Side Highway in Lower Manhattan, officials said. The pickup smashed into a school bus before the driver, Sayfullo Saipov, a New Jersey truck driver who immigrated from Uzbekistan, jumped out and was shot by a police officer, the authorities said.

title: Mnuchin Talks Taxes and That Vanishing Treasury Study
description: Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, may have spent the last week focused on trying to combat terrorist financing in the Middle East, but overhauling the tax code was never far from his mind.

title: Ezekiel Elliott Will Serve Suspension After Injunction Is Blocked
description: Dallas Cowboys running back Ezekiel Elliotts last bid to stave off a six-game suspension was denied on Tuesday when a federal judge in New York declined to block his ban while he appealed the case.

title: Trumps Message to Russia About Mueller
description: Paul Manafort, who led President Donald Trumps campaign during several months in 2016, and Rick Gates, who was also a campaign official, surrendered to federal authorities after being named in an indictment obtained by Robert Mueller III, who was appointed as special counsel in May to investigate connections between the Trump campaign and the Russian government.

title: Pruitt Bars Some Scientists From Advising E.P.A.
description: WASHINGTON  Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, stripped a half-dozen scientists and academics of advisory positions Tuesday and issued new rules barring anyone who receives E.P.A. grant money from serving on panels that counsel the agency on scientific decisions.

title: Carmelo Anthony Is Gone, and Perhaps the Knicks Dont Miss Him
description: Go ahead and check the box on the most important metric of the Knicks young season and perhaps their entire season: the all-important vision thing.

title: Signs of Possible Guilty Plea in Turkish Gold Trader Case
description: With just weeks before Reza Zarrab, a Turkish gold trader who has been charged in Manhattan with conspiring to violate the United States sanctions on Iran, is to go on trial, his lawyers have given every indication that he may be prepared to plead guilty.

title: Slavery Thrived on Compromise, John Kelly
description: In an interview with Laura Ingraham on Fox News last night, the White House chief of staff, John Kelly, said the lack of an ability to compromise led to the Civil War, a statement that would shock, among others, the founding fathers. After spirited debates at the 1787 Constitutional Convention, they included Article 1, Section 2, Paragraph 3 in our Constitution, which said each slave, for legislative representation and taxation purposes, counted as three-fifths of a person. That provision is known as the Three-Fifths Compromise, a term that clearly states that Northerners and Southerners were, in fact, quite able to reach weird compromises on slavery.

title: Lets Waste College on the Old
description: Usually, when a demographic group is significantly underrepresented on elite college campuses, we consider it a problem. But there is one such problem that almost no one seems to notice or care much about. Nearly 30 percent of college undergraduates are adults, defined by the United States Department of Education as 25 years old or older. But at Stanford, the share of undergraduates who are adults is 1.2 percent; at Yale, 0.7 percent; at Princeton, 0.6 percent; at the University of Chicago, 0.2 percent.

title: Trail of Terror in the Manhattan Truck Attack
description: A series of diagrams show points where victims were hit during the attack.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: El Museo del Barrio to Close for Several Months During Renovations
description: El Museo del Barrio, the countrys oldest museum devoted to Latino art, announced on Tuesday that it will close its exhibition galleries and theater for several months as part of a planned renovation.

title: Georgia Tops First College Football Playoff Rankings
description: Defying The Associated Presss poll and much recent history, the initial College Football Playoff rankings placed the undefeated Georgia Bulldogs (8-0) in the top spot, one above the undefeated Southeastern Conference colossus Alabama (8-0).

title: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Stomach Cancer Risk
description: People who carry the stomach bacteria known as Helicobacter pylori are at increased risk for ulcers and stomach cancer. But even when antibiotic treatment has eliminated the bacterium, stomach cancer may still arise. A new study suggests that one reason may be the long-term use of proton pump inhibitors, or P.P.I.s, acid-reducing medicines sold under brand names such as Prilosec and Prevacid.

title: Trump, Niger and Connecting the Dots
description: It is easy to ignore the recent story of four U.S. servicemen killed in Niger, the giant state in central Africa, because the place is so remote and the circumstances still so murky. That would be a mistake. Niger highlights a much larger problem  just how foolish, how flat-out dumb President Trump is behaving.

title: Glasses Are Cool. Why Arent Hearing Aids?
description: If I do my job right, this column might actually change your life. More important, it might change the lives of the people you love.

title: In Praise of Soccers Jack-of-All-Trades, Now Making a Comeback
description: In the year that Bobby Robson coached Barcelona, 1996-97, he was not short of players to praise. His defense was marshaled by Laurent Blanc, his midfield controlled by Pep Guardiola and his attack spearheaded by Ronaldo, the greatest talent of his generation.

title: The Crucial Role of World Series Losers
description: Baseball is a series of definitive moments, but none are quite like the final out of the World Series. Its recorded, and we all, players and fans, claim instant perspective. Win the World Series and everything you experienced before it has led, inevitably and majestically, to this moment. Even previous failure has new meaning, and previous success has been bottled. More important, winning made it worth it all, whatever it was  the rehab from Tommy John surgery, the 111 losses four years ago, the boos.

title: Google Docs Glitch That Locked Out Users Underscores Privacy Concerns
description: Google Docs threw some users for a loop on Tuesday when the service suddenly locked them out of their documents for violating Googles terms of service. The weird part? The documents were innocuous. The alerts were caused by a glitch, but they served as a stark reminder that not much is truly private in the cloud.

title: Ongoing Trump Migraine: His Initial Foreign Policy Team
description: WASHINGTON  One lasted only 24 days as President Trumps national security adviser, done in by his lack of candor about conversations he had with the Russian ambassador. Another has been hauled in front of a federal grand jury investigating Russias interference in the election.

title: A Capital Consumed by Talk of Scandal and Suspicion
description: WASHINGTON  The president seethed with resentment, his party ducked for cover and the opposition chortled with glee. Lawyers counseled clients. Lawmakers tried to change the subject. Campaign veterans fretted that colleagues may be wearing a wire. And everyone wondered about a guy named George Papadopoulos.
